title: excellent outdoor space near the science centre building
text: i have been going to boston in the spring annually and this year i saw something new.  they have this common area outside the science centre building that is amazing.  when we were there, there were two ladies offering free fruit, lemonade, donuts and talking to the people to get feedback about this common area.  there were food trucks to buy food.  in this common area, there were benches with huge pillows to relax on, tables to eat at and tables and benches for larger groups of people.  then there were the games....mini golf, ping pong, a foosball table, huge jenga game, beanbag toss, and i am sure i am missing some other things.  everything was free.  oh yes, there was a giant chess set.  but everything was free and it was in a great location.  our family spent about an hour hanging out here and if we let the kids decide, we would have spent even more time here.  the architecture is incredible.  the people are all friendly.  it was an enjoyable morning.

title: Beautiful, Historic Campus!
text: This is a beautiful, historic campus! Harvard has a strong history and academic tradition. The school offers free, student-led tours around the main buildings on campus. The tour was interesting, saw a few highlights of some of the more historic buildings, and it was about an hour in length. Do be aware that the tour is outside, so if the weather is bad, you might want to consider it for another day. Also, I was a bit disappointed that we weren't able to go inside any of the buildings. That would have been nice, but I understand they have to consider the safety and security of their students.

title: Legendary place and with lots to see
text: Harvard Yard is an iconic campus, and it's fun to feel the buzz.  But there are also many great collections to visit including the newly renovated Harvard Art Museums, the Peabody (glass flowers! And the second largest ethnographic collection in the USA!), and the scientific instruments collection in the Science Center.

title: See the Art Museum
text: The Art Museum got a new addition (Enzo Pianno) a few years ago which really allows you to see the breadth of Harvard's collection in both antiquities and more recent works. There's also a pleasant cafe in the atrium to let what you've seen soak in.The rest of the campus is vast and not all of it contiguous. The Business School is across the river but a world away, feels like a country club.

title: Great to see
text: Harvard is like a separate town on it's own. The campus is surrounded by student shops and restaurants. The campus itself is very beautiful, as all the buildings have been preserved, and although you are unable to enter any buildings, it's a very tranquil area to stroll around. title: The classic private university experience!
text:
If you want to know what to be an exclusive student is like, you have to check this campus. 
Classic Boston architecture, looks like taken from some old british town, really great to see. You can walk around a get amused by pretty much every building. 
Make sure you check the Memorial Cathedral and the small church nearby. The natural history museum is great you have to check it and more important, you can get there by Bus or Subway. Ride the T to Harvard square and walk for a couple of block or find the best bus route (maybe the 1 or the 86) to get there. 
Great campus and awesome architecture!

Enjoyable way to spend an afternoon!

title: A Crimson Masterpiece
text: Once upon a time in a remote outpost of the British Empire a tiny college was founded, and subsequently enriched by the modest estate of Cambridge-educated clergyman John Harvard. He tooketh no selfies, so the statue of him is based on a favorite local pastime: good-natured speculation grounded in research. Behold what nearly four subsequent centuries hath wrought! Enjoy a walk, or sit, in the Yard, a four-season feast for architecture, landscape, and people-watching enthusiasts, and imagine the leaders, both celebrated and notorious, in politics (including eight U.S. presidents), law, humanities, arts, sciences, and business who have wandered through this Crimson space. Walk up the steps of Widener Library, a gift of a grieving mother in honor of her bibliophile son who perished on the Titanic. Visit Memorial Church, and especially the heartbreaking and astonishingly ornate World War I memorial, and be reminded that there are many from privileged backgrounds who do not dodge or scorn the ultimate sacrifice in the service of a larger good. Memorial Hall, with its rich, fantastic woodwork and stained glass windows, is a timely and hauntingly beautiful reminder of an American Civil War that often seems without end. Harvard extends far beyond the Yard area and has endless delights in store, from the Weeks Footbridge over the Charles River (try it at dawn or dusk for an unforgettable many-cupolaed sensory treat) to the Biz School, to the dazzling marbled magnificence of the Medical School Quad, to the green (in the environmental sense) and grand (in every sense) state-of-the-art Wasserstein Hall at the Law School. Consult a map. Set aside ample time. Indulge. Repeat!

title: Harvard
text:
We did a Harvard Walking Tour which is led by a 2nd year Harvard Student Boris. 
We walked through the Harvard Grounds past the Freshman Dorms, The Library, the main grounds area. The whole area around the campus is pretty much all centered around the students. With all the off campus living being right in the centre of the little town. The Campus is beautiful with prefectly manicured gardens and hirsotic brownstone buildings. 70% of the students at Harvard are on scholarship. 
A good tour that goes for just over an hour. Guide was very informative and enthusiastic.

title: Wander in the feet of the great
text: Staying in central Boston we decided to cross the Charles River (by the T) to just savour this world-renowned Ivy League (Harvard) campus.  A very snowy & cold day indeed but we were pleased to go & mouth around.  My only criticism (not least because I'm a Brit) is that there were no open Colleges or Chapels.  No maps or tourist information - like we have in Oxford & Cambridge.  Shame.  Lovely place though.

title: A place that's is "open" but it's all closed
text: I don't like Universities with libraries closed for the public. Knowledge should be open for every one, specially libraries. I was a student at University of Edinburgh, a top 20 University in the world, and it's library is open for everyone :) don't get me wrong, being at Harvard is nice but certainly tells  you a lot when you can't even take a look at it's library. Perhaps is because some graduates will become part of the Arms industry that's is based in Boston :(

title: Fun Stroll Around Campus
text: Had a fun stroll around the Harvard Campus this past Sunday.  We had always wanted to see Harvard, so my wife and I tood the T out to Harvard Square and just hung out.  It was a blast.  I didn't think the campus was anything extra special in terms of beauty, but it was fun mingling with the Ivy League students.  The fun was having lunch in Cambridge and sitting in Starbucks and observing the studies going on and the activity of the town.   Don't misunderstand, if you are like me and just want to see it, it was well worth the short ride out there.  You will be disappointed if you don't go.  Plus, there are some really good eateries near the campus.

title: Highlights list below
text:
I was a student here, and have been visiting every couple of years since, usually for work. Here is my list of things to do if you are a visitor and want to dodge the standard tour:

1. Go see the glass flowers exhibit. Google "glass flowers harvard"

2. Walk through the Science Center and marvel at the poor quality of the classrooms

3. Wander around the square and go to Pinnocio's pizza and get a tomato - basil slice. About as authentic a harvard experience as you will get.

4. The Art museum (I always forget the name) is good.

5. Toward the end of the day grab a drink at the bar of the Harvard Faculty Club. Just walk in like you own the place and say you are going to the bar and ask if they could point you in the right direction. Only do this if you are aged over 40 or are dressed nice. 

6. Walk across the river to the business school and look at the high temple of american corporate craziness. See if you can get into the cafeteria (called Spangler Hall, if I recall correctly). It's nuts.

7. Do the standard tour. It's part of the show.

8. Hang out in Harvard Square. Aside from studying, that's pretty much what the students do...

title: World-Famous? Yes. World-Class? Yes. Objective and Neutral? Absolutely Not.
text: I graduated from Harvard College with High Honors in 1980. Harvard is obviously a wonderful, world-famous school. If you can get in, then go. But Harvard is also a pompous, self-important, narrow-minded school that assumes everyone is uber-liberal. Harvard professors basically vote mindlessly liberal the way San Franciscans do. If that's your thing, then you'll feel 100% at home! If not, tough luck. We're Harvard. We know better. Look: It's a great school to go to, and it will be a great thing to have on your resume. But it's not a bastion of critical thinking and dispassionate scholarship; instead, it's a bastion of Far-Left Pronouncements overlaid on a World-Famous Institution.

title: Intellectual aspiration
text: Harvard University ... it's reputation is big but not as awesome as HU is in reality . The ivy covered buildings , the absent minded professors , the scurrying students and the sleepy libraries ... the awesome museums , the Centres of science , music, art and geography ... if there is an intellectual banquet it is this ! Visit the Harvard Yard and marvel at the prestigious ( and tarnished) names on the buildings ...enter the church and listen to the soaring notes of the organ ... grab a chair and sip coffee on the lawns ... and create memories for a lifetime.

title: Amazing tour
text: My husband and I travelled to Boston with our two teens. The Trolly tours include a stop at MIT. We took a subway from there and Harvard University is just 2 stops away. Tours are conducted by Harvard students every half tours, tickets for which can be bought from the Harvard square. Our guide Ms. Molly who is a 4th year integrative Biology student was very intellectual, engaging, knowledgeable, interactive and witty. She took us around the Harvard campus to see the buildings and gave us information about the history and her experience at Harvard. It was an hour well spent.

title: Bus then two stops on the T
text: We had purchased tickets for the old town trolley tours and they have a stop at MIT, from there it is two stops on the subway system (The T) to Harvard .. There are students waiting outside the station who will give you a tour , I think they charge $12 .. However there is a little kiosk where you can buy a map of the area and the gentleman there informed that the official Harvard tours are free and run on the hour from an office round the corner . So we walked two minutes to the building he had indicated for us and sure enough this was the proper tour . The girl who took it was a fourth year student from Austin Texas ( I've forgotten her name ) , but she was a great guide .. Very informative and pleasant .. She took us through the various areas and explained some of the history of the people and events that had happened here . The tour took approx an hour and I'm glad we did it .. We returned to the subway went back to MIT. Think the station is called Kendal and jumped on the next trolley bus that came along .. Excellent diversion and added to our experience in the Boston area

There are students waiting outside the station who will give you a tour , I think they charge $12 .. However there is a little kiosk where you can buy a map of the area and the gentleman there informed that the official Harvard tours are free and run on the hour from an office round the corner . So we walked two minutes to the building he had indicated for us and sure enough this was the proper tour . The girl who took it was a fourth year student from Austin Texas ( I've forgotten her name ) , but she was a great guide .. Very informative and pleasant .. She took us through the various areas and explained some of the history of the people and events that had happened here . The tour took approx an hour and I'm glad we did it .. We returned to the subway went back to MIT. Think the station is called Kendal and jumped on the next trolley bus that came along .. Excellent diversion and added to our experience in the Boston area

title: Interesting wander about the campus
text: Making the comparison between Cambridge in the U.K. and Cambridge Massachusetts was important to us brits especially as my wife and daughter are Cambridge graduates. We enjoyed a wander about working out which building was which and which architectural style was represented. Worth a visit to stroll through the leafy quads.

title: Definitely worth a visit
text: We booked on line at Harvard Tours, this site is run by students and by booking on line you save a few dollars. The tours leave every 30 minutes from Harvard Square, they bring you through the original university grounds and tell you the history of the university over the 75 minute tour . Our tour guide was a junior from New York City, he did a good job guiding the tour. it was definitely worth the time and money. I would have liked to have more time to explore the Cambridge  area & the area surrounding Harvard.

title: Smaller than I thought it would be
text:
Took a walk from Fenway Park to Harvard, it took me about 30/45 minutes. When I got there I decided to go on one of the official tours, which I had to wait but didn't mind. I watched an Anti-Trump demonstration. Not being US Citizen thought that the students put their arguments eloquently and superbly; kudos to them. The tour guide was very enthusiastic and it was evident that he loved everything about being a Harvard student. His knowledge impressed me and the historical stories he told were first rate and entertaining. Upon completion of the tour I wished him all the best.

One thing, and I guess this is just my personal perception, I thought that Harvard University would be bigger than it was. It's relatively small which surprised me, but when you're one of the worlds most prestigious University you don't need to be big.

The buildings are impressive, and I can imagine that it's been like so since the day it opened. Definitely worth a visit, even if you're not an academic or history enthusiast, it's just a good place to visit.

title: A Perfect Campus
text:
My friends and I visited Harvard University today which is a private university in Cambridge, Massachusetts, established in 1636, whose history, influence, and wealth have made it one of the world's most prestigious universities. We took the red line subway from Quincy Market to Harvard than backed the same route that is cheaper than uber or taxi only need $5.5 round trip. It is also convenience transportation.  When we came out the Harvard station it is the Harvard Square. There are a lot of  restaurants and souvenir shops in Harvard Square. Also, many architectures of Harvard are close to Harvard Square.

Visitors need not pay any fee to enter into Harvard University. We saw  lots of brick buildings and took some pictures in front of these buildings. We are most impressed with is the statue of John Harvard. Actually, at the beginning, we not found it until we notice many people gathered to there. The statue has a nicknamed which is the ‚Äústatue of three lies‚Äù because of all the inaccuracies inscribed on it. The three lies are that is not real John Harvard, he did not attend the College and Harvard University was not founded in 1638. If you think it is interesting, I would recommend you to see it in person.

title: An interesting peaceful walk
text: We caught a bus out here from downtown Boston, just to soak in the Harvard atmosphere.  It was a peaceful walk through the grounds, admiring the building exteriors and watching squirrels bury acorns for winter.  A number of coach tour groups were evident although they were easily avoided.  Lots of good coffee shops are close at hand and the Harvard Book store on Mass Ave should not be missed.

title: Must experience this campus
text: When planning your trip to Beantown, I would highly recommend setting aside a couple of hours to tour the grounds of Harvard University. Not only is it steeped in tradition and a nice historic site, that part of town is bustling with energy. The Harvard co-op is the place to go for any and all Harvard gear. Just be aware that souvenir items are on par with tuition - very expensive!! The only reason why this stop only received 4 stars. Otherwise well worth your time.

title: Great day in Harvard
text: We did the tour which really didn't let you inside any of the buildings, but was worth it just to get some of the stories about Harvard.  The tours are run by students, and also some of the Harvard gift shops help subsidize students.  The town has a very pretty setting and lots of brick buildings - reminds me a bit of an English setting.  We were there while they were practicing for the Cambridge Regatta and it was fun to watch the rowing boats on the river.  We walked all along the river's edge on both sides.

title: For a history buff, taking a tour is informative and fun.
text: I enjoyed our tour of Harvard for it's historical context - from its mid-1600 formation and famous alumni, to its alliance with Radcliffe College, to the 1999 change in diplomas for female students.  One thing that really struck me though was just how many tourists were on the campus.  The Harvard Yard between all the freshmas dorms was filled with tourists, not students throwing Frisbees, on a beautiful, warm, Thursday afternoon.

title: Student guided tour of Harvard Yard
text: Visited while the university was in session. Our guide called Alexander was leading his first tour. He gave us lots of information, was happy to answer questions. and offered about ten minutes over the scheduled hour. There were many tourists on the day of the visit, most on guided visits but others simply strolling through. As a student I might have resented such intrusion, but on the day I was delighted to have the opportunity to see for myself the world renowned campus. I recommend booking via the official university website.

title: I'm so glad we went!
text: Our family of four including two teenagers decided to go see Harvard during a recent trip to Boston & I'm so glad we did.  Cambridge itself is a great area with lots of energy.  Initially, we were going to tour Harvard on our own, but decided to book a tour with Hahvahd Tours which are led by Harvard undergraduate students.  We are so glad we decided to go with the tour.  We learned so much more than we would have exploring on our own.  Our tour guide Cormac was entertaining & really did a great job of providing history & insight into a Harvard undergraduate experience.

title: Well worth a look around
text: I have been to Boston numerous times and never made it to Harvard so this trip we decided to go. Whilst we were looking at the maps and different tours available we were approached by a gentleman who offered to give us a tour. In return he asked that we pay him what we felt his tour was worth. A few other people were also taking him up on his offer and so we joined them. He was very informative of the area and took us to various places in and around the university. The grounds are stunning and I was very pleased we had made the effort to visit. There is so much history in the area and so many stories that I would say, don't just get a map. Get a tour guide. They are worth the 10 bucks or so that you will pay. Without them, you will not get the full experience.

title: Harvard University tour is a must.
text: If visiting Cambridge and not a Yale or Princeton Alumnus, I would suggest you take the Harvard University Tour.  It costs $12, lasts about 10 minutes and is led by a Harvard underclassman.  Our guide was Carmack(?) and he was great.  True, many of his jokes must be told by all the guides but his presentation reminded me of a stand up comic who is dying on stage, pretty hilarious.  The tour goes into the history of the school, notable students, etc.  What I found interesting was that we visited just before the start of school.  It was pretty funny how the new Freshmen were welcomed by current undergrads.  They surrounded the "lost and confused" Freshmen and struck out in a loud/energetic sound and dance routine.  I only wished that I was welcomed like that on my first campus day as a Freshmen.

title: Explore by foot
text:
Harvard is a great place to explore by foot. Give yourself a half a day to explore on your own or with a tour. The architecture is old, classical and conservative. Very different from MIT. If you'd like to take a tour, free student tours are offered by the Harvard Information Center located at 1350 Massachusetts Ave. Be sure to check the online calendar for tour dates and times. It's not always offered.

Alternatively, you can pay for a 90 minute tour through a private company who hire students. This cost $10 and is called "The Hahvahd Tour."

Also, if you'd like to tour the campus on your own, the "Harvard Tour" app is available on both iOS and Android. Free wifi is available throughout the university.

title: Buy a Guide Book and Read Before your begin Walking
text:
The original Harvard Yard and Harvard College is now surrounded by other Harvard esteemed colleges. Some buildings the public can gain access to (although signage lists them as restricted). The interesting parts of Harvard are certainly easy to find, there is so much more to Harvard than the central core of the university. I strongly urge visitors to travel the less trodden paths and view some of the off the beaten path buildings, alleys, yards, and buildings. Many of these offer extraordinary views of art and architecture that is steeped in history. Please, avoid the canned tours and take a few minutes to sit on the lawn and take in the feel of the true Harvard. It is a living institution that happens to be part museum and very much a part of history. 
Is it a good rainy day activity? Yes, if you only have one day. It is a part of Boston that can not be missed. Bring an umbrella if you need to.

title: Want to have a little fun with a friend or family member?
text:
We were in Boston for a week or so, and headed over to Cambridge where we walked around Harvard's grounds - beautiful.

There are gates all around the campus - it appears they're dedicated by different classes, as their year is included in the wrought iron work.

At any rate, walking through the gate gave a sense of entering.  So I called my father (who thinks I cheated myself by deciding to stay home and raise kids) and said "Hey, Dad!  I wanted you to be the first to know, I just entered Harvard!"  Poor guy.  He was so proud in that moment, and so disappointed the next, when I explained that I wouldn't be there more than an hour.

I'm sure that's not funny to everyone, but I thought I'd share for the rest of you...

title: Loved the student led guided tour!!
text:
We wanted to take a free guided tour but we never found the information office so we decided to pay and took a student led guided tour (12$ per person/ buy tickets at Harvard square) which lasted one hour. The tours seem to start at 10am and run every 30min. We took the 10am tour and it was not too crowded which enhanced the experience. The grounds are filled with tourists - you can wonder where all the students are!!
The tour was let by Branson and it was a very enjoyable experience. He was clear in his explanations and provided a lot of funny insights. We walked through the different university buildings (outside only) and learnt a lot about the campus history. Highly recommended. We had a great time!!

title: A university with a history
text: We have learned a lot more about this prestigious University. We went there as we visited family in Boston, and my husband spend a summer there studying. So it was a remembrance for him and maybe the future for our kids. We wanted them to see it and we have been really impressed. Can you imagine that over 68000 students are applying and only 4000 are studying there. The campus is amazing, we booked a tour that Harvard students organizes so you get to know the place better and really wish you were there to study too. Sorry we could not visit the library one of the largest in the US.

title: Good but didn't quite meet expectations
text:
I visited the campus and took a 2hr walking tour. It was easy to get to. Take the red line train about 4 stops from downtown. It took about 10-15 mins and the train arrives just under Harvard Square.

As a tourist attraction it didn't meet my expectations but i still enjoyed it. Having been to oxford and cambridge i maybe unrealistically expected something as grand and picturesque, but harvard isnt quite that. Its very functional, most buildings are off limits and the garden areas are just grass. There is a range of shops and cafes around the Harvard Square.

I would recommend visiting but would suggest taking a tour once you get there.

title: Harvard Campus Tour
text:
Took the campus tour (which was led by the students, I forgot the name but I think there's only one. The stall is on the island in Harvard Square) with my friends and we had an excellent experience. 

The tour guide was Justin, he was funny and awesome!! The way he narrated the whole tour was on point, he walked and waited for most of the group (there's always going to be few people who would take their time and took pictures; me, myself, was one of them). His voice was loud and clear. If you want to do the tour, ask for Justin. You won't regret it. He told many interesting stories about the campus. I'm not gonna say it here, you need to take the tour yourself to hear it.

title: Beautiful
text:
What a beautiful campus. It seems never ending. Old buildings and the museum of natural history is right there ( around the corner from Harvard law school ) there were several food trucks in the square and people playing a giant chess board. 
We walked around in awe for about an hour and saw there were several Tours. We learned the tours were free and you can join up any time ( just remember to tip
Your guide ) :) 
Don't miss Harvard square with the boutiques and the famous Harvard book store.

title: Expectations
text: We came to check out the campus and man I was really disappointed by the grounds.  So ugly, good luck finding any flowers or anything pretty to look at.  The grass was not even well kept.  You would think they could spend a little money on landscaping.  There were tourist everywhere, we did fine without joining a tour.  If you sit outside the steps of Memorial church you will hear several tours stop by and give the run down.  Don't expect to enter many of the buildings, as most are for students, which is expected. The most interesting thing I saw was a truck full of bread.

text: We took a one hour free tour of Harvard that took us through Harvard Yard. title: Harvard University / Visiting the World's leading university is a must when visiting Boston
text: Harvard University was founded in 1632 and is the oldest center of learning in the World . It is rated the best university in the world ahead of Yale , Oxford and Cambridge . It is located on both sides of the Charles River and in a beautiful setting and same for the buildings housing 11 faculties , 21.000 students and 2.100 professors . The endowment fund is by far the biggest in the world with USD 37 billion . Students from 201 countries has attended Harvard . The Harvard Square is a great place for meeting up or having a meal while students are passing by . It is really a wonderful university and well worth a visit .

title: Harvard Yard - Always Busy
text: During the past 6 summers I've had the opportunity make my way through Harvard Yard on my way to and from class. I'm always struck by just how early the tours get going, and how many people are on campus.  Early mornings are my favorite, as it's quiet, shady and very few folks are around. The chairs around the Yard are usually empty in the mornings. By afternoon, it is tricky to navigate my way back through as I weave between tours in various languages and every chair is usually taken. The nearby food trucks make this a great stop for lunch, too.

title: Entertaining and Informative Tour
text: Really enjoyed our one hour tour round Harvard. The buildings take on a new life when you know why they were built , who lived in them and the stories that make up Harvard's history over the last 300+ years. Our guide ( Zach - 2nd year Psychology)  was informative entertaining and encouraged us to ask any questions on student life. did a neat backwards walk throughout the tour as well to keep facing us! $10 per person. Easy to walk.

title: Beautiful campus...historic and modern buildings
text:
In summer, you can sit on the quad in lots of lawn chairs scattered around. Tons of people - most of them tourists - hanging out. LOADS of parents with high school-age children, all of them to marinate in the atmosphere - and hope that somehow a visit pays off come admission time.

Harvard Square is literally outside the gates. It's a little more buffed and polished over the last 25 years, fewer local shops, more chains trying to look ye-old shoppe or hipster modern.

The University has several outstanding museums. Visit their websites to see admission times and rates. Massachusetts residents get into the Harvard Museum free on Saturday mornings.

title: DIY walking tour in Cambridge
text:
I stayed at Boston Park Plaza near Public Garden, and form there I walked over to Harvard University. The thing I enjoy most when visiting a new place is just walking around to really see and experience the area. From my hotel to Harvard, it was a   an-hour-and-12-minute walk, according to Google Maps. If you are an urban hiker and are OK walking this kind of distance like me, read on!

From Public Garden, there are many streets running parallel to one another. I walked on all of them and the Esplanade toward Harvard Bridge. They are all charming. Newbury offers high-end shopping and the view of the Charles River walking along the Esplanade is wonderful. 

After crossing Harvard Bridge, you see MIT. I visited on the 4th of July, so unfortunately everything was closed. Otherwise, I would have been interested in visiting MIT Museum. After seeing MIT, stay on Massachusetts Avenue no matter what Google Maps says. I typed in Harvard University as my destination, and really got lost. So try some other destination or just stay on Massachusetts till you see Harvard. 

The area surrounding the University is very charming, with lots of eateries and shops. The red brick campus is, of course, worth a visit. Now, here's one of the highlights of my walking tour:

Whenever I plan a walking tour like this,  especially on Sunday or major holidays, I really worry about whether or not there are any toilets along the way. ( Harvard and MIT are universities, not amusement parks, people! ). I did some search and found a very recent article saying "the very first public bathroom in the Harvard area made a "grand opening" in February, 2016!  The article sounded like the appropriateness of putting a public loo right in front of Harvard was controversial for many reasons. I was so curious I went to find it, and to see if it's really there.

The bathroom was very clean and  spacious, and very good-looking. Only one stall. For those who go to a bathroom twice a day, it might be laughable for me to write this much about one. But for others, it is an important issue. If I hadn't stumbled on the article about this new addition to the area, I probably would have visited Aquarium on the 4th. 

So, to whomever came up to this idea and made it happen, thank you very much. I really enjoyed visiting Cambridge on Independence Day, 2016.

title: Inspiring visit to world's most prestigious university
text: My 11 year-old did a report for school on FDR.  In her research, she learned that he attended Harvard and has been obsessed with the prospect of visiting this university ever since.  We took a "tour" offered by a free app available for our Iphone and even got to eavesdrop on a tour being offered by a Harvard student.  She told us the story of the library's benefactor, a grieving mother who lost her son on the Titanic.  We hung out in Harvard Yard and strolled through Harvard Square.  All in all, a great visit.

title: No stuffed shirts here!
text:
We were delighted with our Hahvahd tour.   The junior student guide was well trained, informative, and delightful.  And, she is clearly smart and committed to doing great things in life.  

Overview of the history of Harvard, its buildings, and culture.   As I hoped, our 15 yo grandson got a glimpse of what could be in his future.    The discussion of how the university supports its students and conducts campus life was very enlightening.  

We were impressed by the number of student run enterprises on campus; not only giving pay to students but work experience and a lot of business management experience as well.    

We got this tour as an add on to the duck boat tour, but I strongly recommend it even if you have to buy a separate ticket.    

Tour guides are students, we were prepared to make a meaningful tip for at the end of the tour.   That is an important thing for all of us to do.

Overview of the history of Harvard, its buildings, and culture.   As I hoped, our 15 yo grandson got a glimpse of what could be in his future.    The discussion of how the university supports its students and conducts campus life was very enlightening.  

We were impressed by the number of student run enterprises on campus; not only giving pay to students but work experience and a lot of business management experience as well.    

We got this tour as an add on to the duck boat tour, but I strongly recommend it even if you have to buy a separate ticket.    

Tour guides are students, we were prepared to make a meaningful tip for at the end of the tour.   That is an important thing for all of us to do.

title: Beautiful Anytime of Year
text: Of course you should visit Harvard University. It's the country's oldest--in fact it's older than its country--and one of the most famous and prestigious universities in the world. It also happens to be gorgeous. A stroll through Harvard Yard is lovely in every season, though I do recommend summer or fall, and fall more than summer. It's also a good idea to take the tour. As a local, I generally just eat and drink at Harvard Square and use the spot in transit to and from various places. I've never taken the tour, but many of my ESL students have and have loved it. Harvard and Cambridge are essential parts of a trip to Boston though, so don't think about skipping them. You'd be missing out.

title: University tour by a student
text:
Travelled to Harvard via subway from downtown Boston.  Very quick and easy.
It is free to walk around the university
Tour cost $10 each, tickets from newsstand near to subway exit.  Your guide is a Harvard student.  This is a far better way of understanding Harvard than just looking at some old buildings.
Tour last just over an hour.
Our guide was Jake.  An expert at walking backwards.
We had a fantastic time.
Jake was knowledgable, friendly and interactive with our group of approx 10 people.
We learnt a lot about the university, and it's history, without even realising we were being taught.
We had a laugh, enjoyed every minute, Jake made it fun.
The time went so quickly.
I will unreservedly recommend this tour to anyone.

title: History of US Elite
text: This place was our final destination during our 3 day trip to Boston and we wanted to visit here because we wanted to show our kids one of the best schools in the United States. We were hoping that this visit will influence our 10 and 7 year old kids. Campus is large, beautiful and full of energy and kids loved this experience. We also visited the museum and I just felt so much of the national support for these students who will lead the nation one day. Definitely, this is the place people should go to study if they are qualified to challenge themselves to be a leader one day.

title: Great Free Family Outing
text:
There are a variety of gates leading in from all sides of Harvard Yard; be sure to look up to read what may be carved above the gate you choose.  The campus is beautiful with mature trees and lots of shaded lawn that the kids can run across.  The kids may also enjoy climbing the many steps to Widener Library - great photo.  Have them look up Widener Library and who Harry Widener was and why all Harvard students must pass a swimming test.
Memorial Church is directly across from the library.  You may be able to respectfully enter and attend a service there and read the wall to your right where those from Harvard who died in WWII are listed.  Note the 3 Roosevelts.  Why are they on the wall?  Should poor Kermit be there?  Talk about FDR's role in this war.
Find the statue of 3 lies.  Rub it's toe - it's just what you do.  Have the kids tell you the 3 lies.
Find the site of the building occupied by General Washington and his staff during the Revolutionary War...your kids will be able to look this up...they basically took over Harvard, eh kids?  There is a plaque describing the fort built as directed by Gen. Washington at 101 Waverly Street in Cambridge; it's embankments are the only remaining Revolutionary War bits in Cambridge.  Where is this in relation to the Charles River and why did the General have it constructed there, kids?
Parents, explain why the Harvard Science Center was referred to as the Polaroid Building.  Point out the ways in which it really looks like a Polaroid camera (consult your own parents, as necessary).  The kids can look up who funded it.  Why aren't Polaroid cameras and film made anymore?  They were fun.  As fun as SnapChat?  Discuss.
The Harvard Natural History Museum is as amazing as walking around the Yard and worth the cost.  Your kids can't run through it as they can outside but they will be entertained well beyond what they'll expect.  Yes, kids, the glass flowers are glass...you could look it up.

title: I'm probably biased
text:
As a former student I'm probably biased...but really do you need me or anyone else to sell you on seeing one of the greatest schools on the planet?

You can get tours, but you don't really need to. Harvard has tons of free apps you can download and it geo locates to tell you what building you're at and the history of it.

It's truly one of the most beautiful campus' you could ever imagine! It's got incredible architecture and beautiful Ivy everywhere! 

If you aren't a student you're not going to get into the buildings either way, tour or no tour but just walking around the campus is breathtaking! 

If you're in the area you're truly missing out if you don't take the time to go see this marvelous piece of history!!!!!

title: Beautiful campus in a lovely setting
text: After seeing some of Cambridge on the trolley trip I was so surprised  to see how charming the town next to the campus was. The campus is beautiful and the history feels palatable. The green space is lovely and the architecture is beautiful. We didn't have time for a tour but next time we would book it. The  neighborhood surrounding the Harvard Yard is full of shops, restaurants,bars and more. Wonderful selection of souvenirs, lots of choices to grab a bite, great section just to stroll. Great way to spend a couple of hours while in Boston!

text: Harvard is very similar to what you would expect, lots of rich guys walking around, beautiful architecture and famous landmarks. It is definitely worth taking a walk with the rest of the tourist around Harvard Square and some of the buildings that are open to the public. If for nothing else, that to say that you ve done it.

title: It is a beautiful campus
text:
This campus is huge, and beautiful. I have mainly visited the Harvard Yard and some buildings around. The yard is really pretty on the summer, when everything is green and the tress are at is best.
There is something about brick buildings that I find so pretty so for me is what makes this place so pretty, is surrounded of brick and nice old constructions, it makes me wish I was smarter (and with tons of money) so I could study in a place like.

title: A beautiful campus
text: Having spent many years of my life at university, I couldn't come to Boston and not walk around the main campus. Spending time in other sections of the university, isn't the same as visiting the statue and enjoying the scale of the library (outside only for tourists) and having a walk around this great university full of history. Take the time to read the plaques and you get a sense of all that has happened on these grounds.

title: Beautiful Historic Campus
text: Walking around Harvard campus is like walking in history.  Beautiful historic buildings, arches with quotes, statues, and of course lots of students. If you are lucky enough to know a student who is willing to take you into the Widener Library as their guest make sure to do it. The Widener Library was built as a memorial to Harry Widener who died on the Titanic.

title: Grad weekend
text: It was nice to see lots of families around the quad towards the end of graduation week.  Of course there are plenty of old, beautifully academic buildings, all with endowments to keep them looking appropriately old.  Others will comment on Harvard itself... I just liked how modern universities haven't really deviated from this initial layout.

title: Worth a visit.
text:
We visited the campus and the area around it and it was a few hours well worth it.
It was after the graduation ceremonies and the university was now closed so ypu could walk around the grounds without too many people.
It's free to visit but keep in mind that you can not enter buildings etc.
It's only 15-20 minutes from downtown Boston and you could go by subway but even a taxi ride across the river is about 20 dollars each way and that way you could see a bit of Cambridge 
Worth a couple of hours visit.

title: Great Tour of Harvard campus!
text: My cousins and I did the Cambridge & Harvard Tour organized by Free Tours By Foot. It was an amazing experience! The tour guide, David P, was very knowledgable and easy to get along with. He gave us in-depth history and background behind all the major spots. It's unbelievable that the tour is FREE! I whole-heartedly recommend this tour and others organized by them. I have enjoyed four tours organized by them in two different cities and have never been disappointed.

title: Beautiful, Best Univeristy!
text: I visited Harvard as a part of my college visit. It is at the very end of the tour and it. Was raining. Still the excitement within me arose. The tour guide was very friendly, and the campus is absolutely stunning. She talks able it her experiences in Harvard, and despite raining, we saw so many scholars doing their work busily under the roof, not wanting to be disturbed. The campus is magnificent, covered in a low key red, with raining it was added with a partial degree of elegance. After the visit, I feel like I actually fall in love with Harvard, wanting to study there, and wanting to belong there.

title: Become part of history - Harvard Commencement Exercises
text:
My daughter is now a graduate of this University. It is an experience that cannot be matched. My daughter is sad a bit to leave her friends (as a senior - an awesome view from her room). 
380 years of academic history lay within this institution. I took a bit in but not enough. There are museums galore and the arts, and public lectures. 
Take your family, find something that appeals to each. It's all there.
Sports, sailing, science, music, plays, performances of various types.

title: Gorgeous campus
text:
Got a tour from two recent alums.  Lovely campus with relaxed feeling, although it was after classes ended and graduation chairs/tents were being set up.

Very historic, yet it didn't have an uptight pretentiousness that I was expecting.  Pleasant experience overall.

title: Most prestigious
text: Established in1636, Harvard is a private research institute which is the U.S.  oldest institution of higher learning is situated in Cambridge not very far from Charles river. It is named after its first benefactor John Harvard and in terms of prestige, influence , culture and excellence it is the best in the world. It was the founding member of Association of American Universities in1900. It's  dozen campuses are spread out in  the Boston metropolitan area. It's almost 40 billion dollar  financial endowment is the largest in the world enabling it  to offer good aid packages. It operates see verbal museums and large library.

title: Buildings are nice...grounds not so much
text:
The buildings were nice.  But the grounds were a let down.  No flowers, bushes, flowering bushes...you get the idea.  The grass wasn't lush...just thin blades and all of the grass was roped off.  I'm not sure what I was expecting but I figured the grounds would be beautiful and in full spring color.
Wander around for a little bit if you'd like...but I think you would probably enjoy it just as much from one of the hop on hop off trolley tours.

title: Why would you NOT visit?
text:
It's Harvard. If you're in Boston, go visit the campus. DUH. 

My personal guide is a research assistant on campus, and a very good guide indeed. We visited the big library (Widener?) - be sure and check out the room holding this guy's original book collection, including a Gutenberg Bible. 

The history and architecture of this campus is insane. Find a local or someone who works there to give you the tour to be sure you learn all the cool stuff. 

Definitely visit Memorial Hall. Stunning building, inside and out.
translated_text:
It's Harvard. If you're in Boston, go visit the campus. DUH. 

My personal guide is a research assistant on campus, and a very good guide indeed. We visited the big library (Widener?) - be sure and check out the room holding this guy's original book collection, including a Gutenberg Bible. 

The history and architecture of this campus is insane. Find a local or someone who works there to give you the tour to be sure you learn all the cool stuff. 

Definitely visit Memorial Hall. Stunning building, inside and out.

title: Remarkable Harvard
text: A tree lined, lovely oasis in the center of the very desirable Cambridge, Mass. Harvard is historic and welcoming with beautiful, predominantly brick, buildings. The library is grand and expansive and the students and employees are incredibly helpful, friendly and warm. In addition to ranking "the best university in the world," Harvard offers dance and theatrical performances open to the public. These performances rival Broadways best! Harvard Yard is a lovely place to sit and people watch and observe the future leaders of the world.

title: Lot to see - but requires guidance
text: Everybody has heard about Harvard University, and nearby Cambridge, will want to pay a visit. It is very nice to walk around the Harvard Yard, and take a picture nearby John Harvard's statute. You can walk around and grab something to eat at the food trucks located at the plaza, and kind of have a feeling of how it is to be here for longer. But you will need someone to point you out the details about the buildings and the notorious people that lived and studied in there. You can have a free tour that is provided by Harvard University itself; it will take you about an hour and provide you with the needed information. There are also paid tours, departing from Harvard Square. Be aware that you won't be allowed to enter in many buildings like students residencies and the library. Anyway, it's worthy.

title: Historical and Beautiful to Walk the Campus
text: It is an icon and you should walk the area and the campus if you are in Boston and have the time.  I got dropped off in an uber, bought a little campus map at the informational center and walked the campus.  It is full of history and there are a few little tours that you can take if you want to learn more.  I cannot believe how old that University is and on a cloudy day in the later afternoon there was not one student outside enjoying the Harvard Yard!  Then I remembered...it is Harvard and they are probably all inside studying for finals.....   A beautiful University campus.

title: Touring America's oldest (and arguably best) university.
text: Harvard Square is a must see when in Cambridge. The University is our nation's oldest and arguably the best in the world. It's certainly got the largest endowment. It was a treat to tour campus with my son. Any prospective student should visit! Start at the John Harvard statue. Don't miss the library and dining hall.

title: Take your time -- From an Alum
text:
Take your time.

There is so much history on this campus, it's worth the extra time if you can grab a hotel and spend an entire day (Or more) touring the campus.

In my time studying at Harvard I really enjoyed the history, and I know you will too. 

Slow down, take your time.

title: Definitely a walk to remember
text: While spending the Labor Day holiday weekend touring the New England states, we stopped for a few hours at Harvard University on our way to Newport, Rhode Island.  I have always wanted to visit Harvard and walking the campus on a beautiful summer day, where most of the students are on holiday, was a surreal and refreshing experience. The buildings are lovely and there are quaint cafes around the campus. We, however, chose to grab a bite at Harvard Square. Aside from enjoying the walk and food, we were able to take great pictures.

title: An inspiring place
text: We picked up a tour of the University in Harvard Square at the newsagent's kiosk . About $10 each and well worth it as our guide ( a student ) was knowledgeable and entertaining . The tour lasted an hour and covered stories about how the University was founded, the various buildings and alumni. After that we went to have a look at some of the other buildings as there's an interesting variety of architecture .( you get given a useful map so you can see what's where ) . Lovely place,lovely atmosphere .

title: Quintessentially New England
text:
We skipped the tour, having done it before on a previous visit, but still enjoyed wandering around the campus in the spring sunshine.  Harvard Yard is beautiful; the elegant Georgian style red brick halls quintessentially New England and has a very 'old money' feel about it, in complete contrast to MIT down the road which is more cutting edge. Do try to fit in a visit to both to see the contrast.

And of course we stopped at the statue of the John Harvard, the 'Statue of the 3 lies', so called because it doesn't depict John Harvard at all, he was the benefactor rather than the founder of the university and the date is incorrect.

Definitely worth a visit.

title: Getting Smart at Harvard
text:
Being in Boston invites for sure for paying a visit to Harvard. Being in a place having hosted more than 40 Nobel price winners is for sure exciting. You can approach such a visit in many different ways.

The hanging out version:

Breath the culture, mingle with the students, start conversations, ask what people like, sit just down and enjoy the atmosphere, stroll around not missing out the library building offering you the exposer to a lot of very individual persons, who for instance just occupy the benches, hang out in the internet, stretch out and sleep or talk with you cause you seem to have time. Like that you'll spend a jolly day and remember for ever Harvard was a place feeling you good.

Making a museums tour version:

You can of course also book or make a tour for instance and you gonna meet the 
Harvard Museum of Natural History, Harvard University Herbaria, the Museum of Comparative Zoology, the Harvard Universitria and the Mineralogical and Geological Museum and if you've swallowed it all, you may remember Harvard is a place making you smart. Such tours can be booked in local tourist agencies and will cost you about 20 dollars (Jan 2016)

Exploring the surroundings version:

Of course even in times of Netflix and Spotify the students love to meet somewhere and getting entertained. Meaning after looking around and enjoying little caf√©s and bars offering healthy stuff (naturally raised chicken making the premium price of your Caesar Salad for instance) you will find a number of local clubs, to hang out and listen to some good music, playing chess or back gammon in public or dare to sit down and show off playing master mind - just because you may feel so much inspired.

Should you be around in winter times like me don't miss ice skates, because there is mostly an ice scating parcour built up.

Whatever version you choose , have fun !

title: Relax and take a stroll ...
text:
If you want a view off Cambridge and all it has to offer along with Harvard University itself - WALK!

Walk from HSq. through the Yard and back again ... THEN  walk along Massachusetts Ave. towards Central Square, have lunch in Central Square and the walk down River Street to the Charles River and circle back to HSq.
ENJOY!

text: What's more iconic Cambridge than Harvard Yard? Definitely a must-see if you visit Boston or Cambridge. There's plenty of restaurants, shopping, and bars nearby if you need a break.

title: It's Harvard afterall..
text:
Probably one of the things I was most excited about seeing while in Boston, was Harvard University. I mean, it's Harvard afterall, one of the most prestigious universities in the world. 
Harvard University is located in Cambridge, just a short metro ride out of downtown Boston. Once in Cambridge, it isn't hard to find Harvard University since it seems that the little town sprung up because of the University. Book stores, coffee shops and cafes line the sidewalks of Cambridge; everything I had always imagined this little place would be. I love it! 
Once on the campus of Harvard, just walking around is the perfect tour, as the college seems to speak for its self with the beautiful architecture and tree lined sidewalks and walkways. The campus offers tours, but I would suggest looking on line for further details on that. 
I suggest grabbing a picnic and a good book, and sitting under one of the many old trees on the campus. The hustle and bustle of the students going back and forth, the professors running here and there, all make for the perfect afternoon at Harvard University.

title: The foyer of Memorial Hall is memorable!
text:
We visited the campus on a cold night prior to classes starting.  Most building were locked up.  Still I thoroughly enjoyed walking through and reading the various plaques.  We were able to go into Memorial Hall, or at least the foyer which is reminiscent of a castle or grand estate home of a prior century.

Take time to read as many plaques and historical markers as you can.

title: Mythical!
text:
I already completed my post-graduation, but I must admit that I felt quite attracted by what this mythical College offers to its students during the free presentation I attended. Those presentations are actually for potential students and their parents, and you might find it a bit long if you are not there to apply, but it is quite interesting, it is free and it is followed by an interesting campus visit.
If you visit Boston do not skip Harvard, it is a beautiful place full of fun stories and museums. You can plan a full visit there (easy to access by public transport from Boston).

title: Amazing trip
text:
I visited Harvard as a tourist and was amazed. The campus it's self is beautiful, the atmosphere is very chilled and there are lots of tourists around taking pictures. The surrounding area has a lot to offer as well, retail shops and souvenir shops , places to eat, cafes etc. you can make a day out of it visiting Harvard or just take a quick trip there as the train form Boston city to Harvard is only around 15 minutes. 

Harvard was everything and more than you would expect from seeing it in movies and is defiantly a must see if in Boston. 

Hope this helped missmemoir.com

title: The oldest institution of higher learning in the United States
text: Harvard University was founded more than a century before the American Revolution.  By now this most well endowed institution sprawls out over much of Cambridge and neighboring Boston.  The architecture of the undergraduate campus is impressive.  They house such fine institutions as the Museum of Natural History, which has a great collection.  One irritant:  the library is completely inaccessible without a university ID.  This seems unnecessarily effete:  I don't want to check out books, just browse.  Nonetheless, my wife, daughter and son in law enjoyed strolling about the grounds

title: Take the Student led Harvard Tour !
text: This was such an enjoyable free activity! We began the morning by grabbing a quick breakfast at Peet's in Harvard Square. But we were disappointed that they don‚Äôt toast bagels. The day was a perfect, sunny, crisp fall day with lovely reds, yellows & golds just spilling from all the trees. You register for the tour up to half an hour before it begins. Our tour guide was a current Harvard student who was so entertaining, funny & personable that it made the time fly by. He assured us we could ask him anything & he knew all the fascinating historical facts behind the buildings we visited which helped everyone truly appreciate the surroundings that much more. Don‚Äôt forget to pass beneath the massive iron Harvard gate that students must pass beneath twice while at Harvard ‚Äì once when they enter the school & once when they leave upon graduation. Afterwards, we wandered through the massive Harvard bookstore nearby to buy some T‚Äôs & souvenirs. We discovered that right next door to the bookstore is a street vendor selling some of the identical T‚Äôs & sweatshirts for much less !   So explore a bit but definitely take in the student led tour.

title: Campus Meeting
text: If you're visiting Boston and looking to explore some of the historical attractions in the area I would recommend a stroll through Harvard's school grounds.  It's a truly majestic campus with old hardwood trees and beautifully architected buildings. title: Diversity Explosion
text: If you're in the Boston area, take the Red Line to Harvard Square and walk around. The people, stores, restaurants and the air will open up a whole new world. You will never be the same regardless of the time of your visit. In the Fall is the best time because the colorful leaves create an ambiance you will not forget. It's not too cold or too hot and perfect walking weather around the Charles River to view the heavenly scenes. All throughout the year you will bump into tourists and people taking in the Harvard air...go visit - you won't be disappointed.

text: There was a street festival complete with a parade the day we visited Harvard University. This was a complete surprise and we enjoyed watching the parade and seeing all the groups represented. We just wanted to enjoy the grounds and the people watching.

title: From Connecticut to Gaby: Our Wonderful Tour Guide
text:
I went on the Free tour with a good friend and we had a great time! I believe our tour guide's name was Gaby. She was awesome! I loved how real and authentic she was. She was extremely knowledgable. The best part of going on the tour with Gaby is that she always made people feel comfortable to approach her with any questions. She did a fine job talking about the financial aid process. This is by far the best college tour I've ever taken! 

I was unsure of the gratuity situation which is unfortunate because she was stellar!

- Cory and Elaine

title: A place to call home
text: I studied at Harvard, but I still enjoy going there.  There are some hidden places on the campus to see.  Try the Divinity school yard, have lunch at the business school.  There are always lots of events on the campus and so if you are around, please do visit.  A few other things you may want to visit is the observatory, and the many museums on campus.

title: A living history book.
text: Take time to walk around the campus and you will see history come alive.  Posted around campus are plaques commemorating important events over the last 300 years.  For example, the freshman dorm housed troops that fought in the revolutionary war!  Make sure you go into the main library.  It has fascinating architecture.

title: Overrated
text: Are people reviewing this place as a university, to get an education? Or as a tourist site? It's a pretty poor tourist site. A handful of old buildings, some really great museums (both art and natural history). But the campus itself is not particularly photogenic. The old campus is ivy covered brick but that takes a2 minutes to appreciate. Also, parking is terrible.

title: Boston's #1 tourist attraction
text: ... by number of visitors, for good reason. It's the most prestigious university in the world, and a major historical site, with several excellent but not-too-large museums. I recommend a campus tour, though these are variable, and a visit to at least the Fogg Museum (fine art). One interesting thing about Harvard is that it's not physically impressive compared to many larger campuses across the country - it's not all about buildings.

title: Worth Seeing
text:
This is an icon of America and should be seen. It is an experience. I would describe it as a bee hive.There a people everywhere walking talking someone from all over the earth in one place. They make a beautiful collage of sight and sound. These students and visitors seem to fall into an easy cadence. These kids do not seem rushed or anxious. The campus is full of seats and toys. ie; the colorful chairs in the square and the exercise stations on the walk way. Make sure to check out the shops and  eateries in the mall entrance. Don't over look the lunch trucks. A walking tour is fast paced and full of information that you can not see by looking. There is a lot to see and may not be accomplished in one visit.
It is good for home schooling, dates and people watching. The students are dressed in enough interesting garb that photo studies of them in contrast to their surroundings would be fun. a trip to the museum should be a specific stop as there is so much to see. There is a cafe and in court seating.
This venue is in town. The space is smaller than anticipated. Parking is at a premium.

title: Wonderful student-led tours!
text: Harvard is a magical place and it's energizing just to walk the campus. A great way to do this is to visit the Information Center (just next to Au Bon Pain at the center of Harvard Square near the T stop) and get a ticket. It's free. The tours are led by students and, in general, are really well done. It's fun to hear the tour guide's stories, along with some fun history. If you're in the area it's definitely worth a visit and a tour.

title: Mike & Micah Lose a Bunch of Kids in the Woods
text: Amazing play at the Loeb Theater at Harvard. Yes, my daughter has a non-speaking role in it, but it is the writing that stands out in this play. One more weekend remaining.

title: An invigorating place.
text:
We spent the afternoon here, we wandered around the campus, taking in the atmosphere, enjoying the beautiful architecture, sitting around on the colourful chairs, people watching. We didn't bother with the tour, but there were plenty of tours to be had.

We were lucky to see the trees in their Autumn colours, it's very beautiful place to visit.
We went into the Natural History Museum and the Peabody museum. It was disappointing that you couldn't go in any of the churches. 
Lots of great places to eat and drink in the town. There were some market stalls along side the campus, selling fruit etc and some snack bars selling food and drink, but we waited until we were back in town.

title: Country's Oldest College
text: Cupolas with weather vanes adorn many of the old buildings on this lovely wooded campus.  Harvard Yard is not unlike many other college campuses with its wooded diagonals crossing from buildings added around a long rectangular central yard.  The only downside is the sheer volume of people in such a small area.  It must have been much quieter in the 1700 or 1800's.

title: The Official Harvard Tour and a glimpse of Harvard University.
text:
I was in Massachusetts, USA, and since I was visiting a cafe near Harvard University, it was only natural for me to visit Harvard University. As I had only about 2 hours to spend at Harvard University, I decided I could get a glimpse of some of the highlights of Harvard University by attending one of the Official Harvard Tour.

The Official Harvard Tour has its earliest tour of the day start at 10 a.m. As I was in Harvard area very early, I signed up for the tour way before 9.30 a.m. I subsequently learnt that it was helpful to be early to sign up for the Official Harvard Tour. The tours were so popular that the 10 a.m. tour was fully booked before 9.45 a.m. However, as registration starts only one hour before a designated tour, it does help to plan ahead the visit to the Harvard Events and Information Center in Holyoke Center so as to secure a place on the Official Harvard Tour.

The Official Harvard Tour was led by one of the student volunteers. In addition to attending the Official Harvard Tour, I bought myself a copy of "A self-guided walking tour of Harvard Yard and surrounding areas".

The Official Harvard Tour brought us to various locations on Harvard Yard such as the Massachusetts Hall, the Harvard Hall, the Science Center, the Memorial Hall, the Widener Library and the site of the John Harvard Statue.

I love the spaciousness of Harvard Yard, and it was a lovely experience being there on a day in summer.

During the tour, I learnt that the Memorial Hall is the building whereby first-year students of Harvard would dine in so as to foster a sense of community. The Massachusetts Hall is the oldest building that is still standing at Harvard. I felt privileged to be visiting Harvard University which has a long history.

It would be nice to offer a gratuity at the end of the tour.

If any one wants more after the Official Harvard Tour, I heard that there is a fun alternative to the Official Harvard Tour. It's the Hahvahd Tour.

title: Definitely Worth the time
text: As a retired teacher, it was a real thrill to be able to walk the grounds of Harvard.  I was mainly interested in seeing Memorial Hall and the Science Building's first computer, and these did not disappoint.  I had done some research on what we wanted to see and where it was located on campus, so we were able to walk the grounds around 8 a.m. in a self guided tour.  Some of the buildings were closed for special services, like the chapel, but it was still nice to get to see the main section of Harvard from the outside.

title: An Icon of Higher Education
text: Harvard is one of the foremost Universities of the world. The campus is a beautiful blend of old buildings side by side with new modern structures. The streets and squares reek with the history of modern day science and the philosophy of inventions and discoveries. The Statue of John Harvard the founder is a popular spot where most tourists love to take a picture holding on to the founders brass boots. It is so popular that the tip of the shoe alone sparkles( due to friction from regular touching) while the rest of the statue is black.

title: Its like a dream come true.
text: Visiting the Harvard Business School during my Boston Visit was like a childhood dream come true. I spent 4 hours at this place and also attended a MBA class as a visitor. title: Student led tour of Harvard Yard is excellent!
text:
Visiting Harvard University is just a subway trip away from Boston.  The meeting point is very close to the red-line Harvard Square station.

The tour is led by students and operates every hour on the hour.  It is led by students and is very informative.  The tour lasted about 1 hour.  Go to the Harvard University website to find out more about their student led tours.

The campus is a nice stop when you are in Cambridge!

title: Beautiful campus
text: Gorgeous campus with plenty of picturesque places to sit, linger, and contemplate all that is wonderful about Boston. Step in the arched brick campus walls and you are instantly enveloped in history. Beautiful old trees shade walking paths through the grassy quad. The farmer's market is an added bonus.

title: Nice way to spend an hour or two
text:
We enjoyed an hour walking round Harvard Square and Harvard Yard. We meant to also visit the book shops but there was an Oktoberfest street festival going on so we got waylaid!

The food trucks at the other side of the yard were a nice surprise and the ice cream was particularly welcome on a hot day.

title: Fun tour by Harvard sophomore
text:
A fun 1 hour tour led by Harvard sophomores. Our guide,  Carmack,  was a lot of fun.  He really has a lot of knowledge about the history Harvard as well as about the architecture of the place.  He also combines a lot of humor and anecdotes from the campus life.  Jokes about Harvard's main rival,  Yale,  are a big part of this tour as well.  
The tours go out every 30 minutes and start just next to the Harvard metro station.  
10$ well spent!!!

title: A Tour Worth Taking
text: Harvard tours are led by Sophomores (2nd year graduates) every 30 minutes at a cost of $10pp plus tips for the guides. The tour takes about 70 to 75 minutes and provides an opportunity for photographs as well as questions of the tour guides. Our guide (Derek) was exceptionally good with a sound knowledge of the history of the University that was established in 1636 by the Massachusetts Bay Colony. It adopted the name of its first benefactor, John Harvard who donated his cow pasture as the site where most buildings now stand. Unfortunately, entrance to buildings is not available to the public but nevertheless, the tour revealed many interesting historical facts.

title: Good to visit only if you're in the vicinity
text: Everybody knows the Harvard University by name, so since I was in Massachusetts, I decided to make a trip to visit this renowned university. However it wasn't a great welcome for me as it was quite a pain having walked the entire yard only to realise the 'visitor centre' for the tours is actually located OUTSIDE the campus building.. After we finally reached the centre, we were told that the hourly tours were fully booked and we had to wait for the next hour. Opted to purchase a $2 Harvard self-guided tour map which turned out to be the better choice because that allowed us to choose which sites to visit and see and which to skip rather than to go to every single one which can be time consuming and to some extent boring or repetitive. Don't get me wrong, the place is nice but having been to other famous universities, Harvard does pale somewhat in comparison and isn't really worth the traveling out just to see the school.

title: Beautiful but we expected to be more impressed by the #1 university in the world
text:
Don't get me wrong, Harvard is a nice campus. Is has a lot of history and is actually pretty impressive. But as a university campus fanatic, I am more looking at the architecture. The style at Harvard is beautiful. The thing is, I was really expected to fall on my back. I have bean a student at McGill in Montreal, and our campus is known to be stunning. I guess it may be hard to beat it, but I have seen plenty of pictures of other american campuses that are wonders of architecture. Sadly we did not have the time to pass by, but I think MIT offers more on that matter. I did love the school of business though. 

Important point for anyone planning to visit, it is VERY LARGE. Plan for at least 2h00 to visit the most important schools and be ready to walk A LOT. 

A good tip: there is free wi-fi as you arrive at Harvard Square. Take the time to download the PFD map of Harvard, which can be saved in Ibook (for IPhones...). Saved me a lot of data to get around the places.

title: Nice place to walk around any season
text: Harvard is known to be intimidating and traditional, however, when you visit the school and the square you discover that it is really welcoming and diverse. There are several entrances to the main Harvard yard and students, families and couples walk around and do various things including picnic in the summer and fall. In the winter is it a great place to sit and appreciate the serenity of snow and see students from all over the world passing by. They could have more sitting areas inside the main yard, but just outside of it they have several restaurants and cafes. It is wonderful to hear locals play their music and at times perform.

title: You Can Feel The Tradition of Centuries!
text:
We are in Boston for 3 days and decided to explore MIT and Harvard.
Both are landmark institutions that defy categorization.
But Harvard is the quintessential University!  It is referred to deferentially by all who have dealt with its graduates.  
To walk the Yard, see the buildings, feel the traditions - it was well worth our trip out here.

title: Worth the walk to Harvard !
text:

title: Highly recommend Hahvard tour
text: If you only have a short time to visit Harvard take the red line train from Boston city centre and get off at Harvard Square. The Hahvard tour guys are just outside the station when you arrive. A Harvard student will give you an amusing tour of the university and explain its history and culture for the grand sum of $10. The tours go every half hour. Our guide was Ross and he was very informative and amusing but I'm sure any of the guides would be. After all they are students at Harvard.

title: Student Led Campus Tour
text:
We were walking around Harvard Sq. and my kids wanted to see the Harvard campus. I've walked through the yard many times, but never had taken a tour before. We bought tickets at the news stand in the square and went off for our tour.

Our guide was a student named Cormac who was a rising Sophomore. This tour was excellent! Took the family and kids (middle school age). Cormac was energetic, enthusiastic, had a great sense of humor, and very informative. He kept the tour entertaining and educational at the same time. 

I would definitely recc a student led tour if you want to actually learn more about the school, campus, and architecture as opposed to just walking by the buildings.

title: It's Happening at Harvard!
text:
Harvard University and its courtyard were spectacular!  It is one of those experiences, free of cost, that leave you in awe.

The grounds were verdant and the structures were majestic and rich in history.

There are tours led by Harvard University students. I learned some fascinating facts, like women were not granted the same degree as men until 1998.

There are some restaurants nearby that you could take a break. I highly recommend you to explore this oasis in Cambridge.

title: Eye opener on student info session
text: We took our high school age children to Harvard and MIT for info sessions and tours - all in one day.  MIT was nice but Harvard was excellent - the info session was insightful, led by an admissions counselor and 2 current students who gave their opinions, answered questions and had a rapport with the counselor that made it engaging.  It was far from the stuffy atmosphere we expected.  There was an emphasis made throughout for everyone to get the feeling there was a family atmosphere at Harvard.  The video presentation at the beginning was entertaining.  The student-led tour though was somewhat disappointing and while we know some of this may be due to the personality and knowledge of the student leading it, we never went inside any buildings - dorms, classrooms, library or any others; meanwhile at MIT it was more immersive and we felt like we knew what life would feel like there through our own eyes, not just what was told to us.

title: Student tour
text: The student information lecture was fabulous and inspirational. Followed by student led tour that was just so-so because we didn't get to go inside any of the buildings.  Student tour guide was energetic and informative.  Biggest complaint is the severe lack of public restrooms on campus.  You have to go across the street to the campus center and wait in line for a really smelly and dirty bathroom.  I would think Harvard would be better equipped to serve visitors.

title: The most beautiful campus ever
text: If visiting Boston, make sure to leave room for the beautiful Harvard campus. We signed up for a guided tour, lead by one of the student, and it was truly lovely. It was fascinating to learn about Harvard's history and to catch a glimpse of life on campus, daydreaming about how it would have been to be lucky enough to study in such a wonderful institution. The Harvard bookshop is also a goldmine - make time for it, but avoid my mistake: I was holed up there for two hours :)

title: Campus Reflects Why This is One of the World's Greatest Schools
text:
Although visiting Harvard was never on my "bucket list," I knew that visiting Boston would include a visit to this hallowed institution.  

I didn't take the tour - but went with a friend who had attended Harvard (and who now works at MIT).  The campus is magnificent (bring good walking shoes!), and to try and explain everything I saw would be diminishing the overall scope of the place.  Lots of incredible/older buildings, green space, history - you name it.

Also, go to the "edges" of campus and you'll experience street performers, shops, and food trucks.

title: Great summer program at Harvard!
text:
Although the weather at Cambridge was rather odd dropping some 14degC from 21degC to 7degC in a day on 31 May (Sun), the temperature climbed to a comfortable 20degC by the end of that week and it made walking around the Harvard campus so pleasant.

The Harvard campus is well-organized so getting around campus was easy.

title: What an amazing insight
text:
I took the official Harvard Uni tour which is free and is conducted by the students of the Harvard running hourly from 10 am to 3 pm. It starts at the Harvard visitor info centre.
It was so fabulous , our guide Nathan doing his secnd year stats was superb. He told us Harvard history showed us completely around , unique heart wrenching stories of the Library and inside superstitions of Harvard Community which the community completely believes in.What a fabulous time I had, came back enriched.
From there I had food at one of the food trucks in the square outside Science Bldg and then went to their very fine Harvard Art Museum.
A day to cherish ...:):)
