title: America's Cambridge . . . IN Cambridge!
text: 25 acre campus, of which you will only need to see a small part to have the 'Harvard Experience'.  Educational home of 44+ Nobel laureates, several U.S. Presidents and hundreds of major contributors to both American and world civilisation.  Your experience will be different if you are there during the school year or over the summer months.  Take the T redline to Harvard/Cambridge.  Smith Campus Information Center is right around the corner on Dunster Street, and this is where you sign up for the free Student-led tour.  Of course if you wish, you can pay up to $20 per person through Viatour, Duck Tours and others.  You will see the highlights of both Harvard Yard and Harvard Square areas, such as Massachusetts Hall (where both John Adams and John Hancock bunked as freshmen) Memorial Hall, the statue of 'John Harvard' in front of University Hall (touch his leg for luck), Sever Hall, Widener Library and the Lampoon offices.  Entry is restricted to many locations due to campus security concerns.  In the Harvard Square area you will see the Plaza, Winthrop Park and Mount Auburn Street.  Tour ends near the Shop / Bookstore so you can get souvenirs.  Many eateries close by (though some tour versions include either a stop at the Harvard Museum of Natural History, or lunch at a restaurant called 'Fire and Ice'.  Enjoy!

title: Lovely campus with a long traditional history and academic achievements!
text:
We were here in the early morning (around 8am) as part of our day tour in Boston and this was the first stop of the day. Upon arrival, we were impressed with the campus, with satellite kind of clusters among academic schools, hostels, retail and F&B outlets, among many others. We were also attracted to the various red-brick buildings. They were very nice and magnificent and solely the property of the University. In deed, this place was just like a mini-town by itself and its full of energy, vibe and activities on going.

We walked around the campus and soon we came by the most visited place in the campus. The statue of the sitting "Mr Harvard". Many people came forward to be photographed and touching the "leg" and hopefully their children/grandchildren will be blessed to be as smart. Haha, a myth? Anyway, just to clarify that this person was not Mr Harvard (the founder of the institution) himself. As in those days, the university was unable to find a photo of Mr Harvard himself when erecting a monument in honour of him, it organized a contest to look for the "most good looking" person and selected the winner to have the monument made after him. So this "Mr Harvard" was handsome. This story was shared to us by our guide.

The campus was lovely and serene, with buildings surrounding greenery landscape and with chairs and benches around for students or visitors to sit and rest while enjoying the beauty of the campus. There was a train station in the campus, besides many nice architectural buildings like churches as well.

So we walked around the campus with a feeling of being a "Harvard" student and somehow feel "proud" to be one as the university is world ranked Number 1.

We came by the campus circle where eateries, cafes and retail shops were located and had our breakfast there. People here were orderly and well mannered and polite. Prices here were reasonable and cheaper than elsewhere. Thereafter, we walked around the gift and book stores nearby, grabbing up some books and souvenirs.

Finally, we landed at the Graduate School of Arts and Social Sciences where I caught up with my associate for a while. Visited briefly on the LTs as well and was briefed about the history of the university and the years of transformation. I was then led to the Co-op store, ran by the students on vacation and bought some gift items as well as a form of support.

It was a lovely walk-around trip in Harvard university in Cambridge in Boston. The feeling was so closed to heart, perhaps due to the fact that I am an academic too. Shortly later, when returning to my coach, the place got busier and more pedestrians crowd jostling among buildings, traffic lights and cafes. Well, its the start of another day in campus!

Highly recommend for a visit!

text: I just enjoyed walking the campus, and sitting in the chairs under the trees in Harvard Yard at the center. The disappointing thing is that most libraries and exhibits are out of bounds if you don't have a student ID, even just to take a peek. There was a farmer's market today (every Tuesday) on the square that was fun, with live music and food trucks.

title: I was there for a college reunion
text:
I was able to walk from the hotel to Harvard Square on a clear day.
Visited Peabody Museum and the "new" (renovated and expanded) Harvard Art Museum.    There's nothing quite like a Harvard Commencement.  This year Renee Fleming (an honorary degree recipient) sang  and Gov. Duvall Patrick, another honorary degree recipient, spoke in the afternoon to the Harvard Alumni Association.

title: Informative, worthwhile.
text:
We got free tickets to do the Harvard tour when we purchased our Duck Tour tickets.  The tour was really good, definitely worth while to learn about what the different buildings are, the history of the University and get some insider info and perspective as it is the students who take the tour. 
Joe was our tour guide and he did a great job, really friendly, funny and v informative.
The tour only lasts about 1hr and we took the T to get there from Boston.

title: I love Harvard!
text: I had the immense joy of actually spending a semester here and everyday got to see the awesomeness around Harvard. I was shocked to see that so many tourists actually come here, but it was quite heartwarming as there are so many things to see on campus even if you are visiting. My parents loved spending days at the many museums, galleries and libraries and as its close to everything, its the perfect place for a day visit.

title: Planned visit.
text: We planned this for sometime whilst we were here, and it did not disappoint, the place was like the grounds of Oxford and Cambridge, England, with its historic architecture and deep history. The day was beautiful and sunny, we sat for sometime on the main lawn near the entrance and took in the feeling of being somewhere where history was made, reading through a list of famous people who at one point walked these paths in their time. We visited the whole place, and I can say it was a marvellous, and Well worth it. We didn't pay for the tour, we just made our own way round, and grabbed info from their website as we went.

title: Cambridge &Harvard
text: This awas a very straightforward trip if you do not object to changing stations on the rapid transfer system. Start at Prudential underground station which is just around the corner from the  Sheraton and was exteremly convenient for most of our travels! For Harvard you change to the red line which takes you right to Harvard square. The tou of the university was interesting and funny with a 4th year student who directs theatre and had already been offered a position with a New York company!

The grounds were beautiful also. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

title: More history here than you might think
text: Yeah, it's old, but it's still just a university, right? There's more history here than you might think, considering how many presidents and famous people have walked these grounds. I highly recommend the student led tour that you can join in Harvard Square.  The most amazing part to me was that the top floor of Massachusetts House is still used as a freshman dorm, where students can be assigned the same dorm rooms used by John Adams and John Hancock.

title: Great University
text: What an impressive campus. Honestly I have imagined the university area to be a bit smaller, so I was pretty impressed when getting handed a map about the area. I would recommend to do a guided tour or just to walk around and check it out. We went there in May, so the final exams where going on, and it was pretty empty around the campus.  So I would recommend to visit the university during the semester and not in the end of it. Impressive architecture and lovely parks.

title: An amazing and interesting walking tour of Harvard University
text:
A great value walking tour of the amazing Harvard Uni with our fantastic, funny, knowledgeable and charismatic tour guide Lelaina, a recent graduate who delighted us with stories and the history of Harvard. What an amazing experience to be able to attend Harvard!
The grounds and buildings were full of history and tradition with Lelaina telling us a few stories about famous past students and the buildings themselves, particularly the amazing library. We also walked around some of the student quarters and finished up at the Harvard shop run by students. We bought some stuff of course!
This tour has a very high rating from us for the importance  of its history and the people who have attended in the past; and for the people who may attend in the future. And for our tour guide who brought it all to life for us with our brief visit.

title: Yet another time!
text: I have visited Harvard multiple times including this latest visit. Parking is a struggle in and around Cambridge so if you find a good spot to park, do so and enjoy a short walk to the University. The university grounds are usually tourist filled and everyone comes here to take a picture with the statue of John Harvard in the center of the square. The old buildings are great to watch and you can visit the library during open hours. Harvard Square in front of the campus has some restaurants and very little shopping. But I would not recommend shopping here. There are much nicer places a little further away.

title: Visited HARVARD UNIVERSITY GROUND, found it interesting but not thrilling
text:
We visited HARVARD UNIVERSITY in BOSTON just 2 weeks ago, and strolled around the well kept grounds, to get an impression how it would be  to study there.  The grounds are in the middle of town, and I found, that although it is very famous, there is not the peace and calm there, that it would benefit the students.

It is pretty crowded there, with all the people visiting town, and the buildings are for sure well built.  But if they are still suitable for a more modern way of studying is the question. 

I must admit, it is a famous university,
it has lots of reputation,
the students have all the advantages of being hired after they studied there,
but..... I would prefer a different university to do my own studies if I would have to
do it again.

It is just too restrictive, too formal for my liking.  But I am an old geezer, and that might
be the reason why I do not fall into the trap of reputation of some institute.

title: Wonderful Tour of Harvard
text:
Loved this walking tour of Harvard University led by Eli on May 17th.  He was informative, humorous and full of fun facts.  Eli is so talented, he can walk backwards faster than I can walk forwards!  We covered the main campus - Harvard Yard, Widner Library and several dorms.  He had stories about each of the buildings including why they were built, who lived there and other interesting facts.  

You can't cover the entire campus in a little over an hour, but this gave you some fun facts and the opportunity to ask questions.  We bought our tickets at the news stand near the info desk about a half an hour before the tour.  So, probably no need for reservations.  The price was the same as the on-line price.

Eli also recommended a lunch spot that was just great, Grendel's.  I strongly recommend the portobello reuben.

title: Tour Of The Campus.
text:
Guided walking tour of the campus with Eli. This guy was extremely knowledgeable,he had many informative tidbits of information. He was funny, witty and his dialogue was riddled with puns which kept his,all aged, audience attentive. 

He told us that his concentrator was Human Evolutionary Biology and his secondary was drama! I will definitely be looking for him on Broadway in the not too distant future. 

I highly recommend this tour and if you manage to get Eli it will be a bonus. 

Good luck in your future endeavours Eli

title: Nice walk and photo-taking
text:
The University, being an Ivy League, is something one of us wouldn't like to miss. And when you're already in Boston, don't miss this, it's a few minutes drive from the city. 

Strolling around and in the campus premises is a good exercise. Walking past the Harvard Square, you'll see inside the campus John Harvard's statue and the Library. Unless you want and intend to get in this University, I don't think you need to walk all around and see the entire campus. Nevertheless, it is interesting to see and be in its vicinity. Missing university days.

title: Ivy League,splendour
text: A beautiful campus full of some of Americas Brightest. I was fortunate enough to see some of the engineering labs and the clean lab in particular. The gardens are well maintained and the architecture is stately. I went into the chapel and library. Beautiful buildings with memorials to those from Harvard that had given their lives. I also went into the museum of natural history. An extremely interesting museum and in particular an old fashioned setting for many of the displays which showed the part of the extensive collection used for education over the years. Particularly impressive are the glass flower displays

title: "When I was at Harvard..."
text:
How many of us have wanted to say, "When I was at Harvard..." Well, for $10 you can! The 90 minute tour of the Harvard campus is a really great way to glean a little about the history of this great institution. 

The tour is conducted by Harvard students and our guide, a sophomore from Vermont, was excellent. She was fully conversant with the history, had an engaging personality and a great sense of humor. 

It was interesting to hear about the 'back stories' of some of the personalities who have made this institution a world leader. It wasn't all 'historic' in that sense; we were introduced to two of the university's modern influential characters: Gates and Zuckerberg. 

The Harvard student led tour is a great experience.  Afterwards, hang around Harvard Square and enjoy the ambience.
translated_text:
How many of us have wanted to say, "When I was at Harvard..." Well, for $10 you can! The 90 minute tour of the Harvard campus is a really great way to glean a little about the history of this great institution. 

The tour is conducted by Harvard students and our guide, a sophomore from Vermont, was excellent. She was fully conversant with the history, had an engaging personality and a great sense of humor. 

It was interesting to hear about the 'back stories' of some of the personalities who have made this institution a world leader. It wasn't all 'historic' in that sense; we were introduced to two of the university's modern influential characters: Gates and Zuckerberg. 

The Harvard student led tour is a great experience.  Afterwards, hang around Harvard Square and enjoy the ambience.

title: It was a good overview tour
text: I took the student-led tour. It was informative. I was surprised how poorly the tour guides (this was the official tour for the University) and the people on the tour are treated while on campus. There was one instance of what I took to be a professor openly mocking our tour guide and people in another building telling our tour that we could not stay in their building - it was only for people associated with the University. However, the lore of Harvard managed to over-ride the snobbishness of some of its staff. I then extended my tour by walking over much of the rest of the campus - a fascinating campus to explore.

title: A Beautiful and Historic Campus
text:
Few universities boast as beautiful and as historic a campus as Harvard. If you want to see one of the oldest universities in the United States, a tour of Harvard is worth your time. The Harvard Yard is both aesthetically pleasing and immaculately maintained; and when you walk through the arches to enter the yard, you quickly realize you are stepping back into history-- in fact, some of the buildings go back several hundred years. 

The campus has a number of excellent museums which are open to the public, and the Harvard Archives are a delight for any historian or researcher who wants to learn more about the many famous people who attended Harvard.  You don't have to be a student to appreciate what the Harvard campus has to offer, from art and natural history exhibits to educational lectures to music festivals; and if you take the tour, you will also see many interesting varieties of architecture.  It is not surprising that so many out-of-town tourists make sure a visit to Harvard is part of their trip to the Boston/Cambridge area. While walking around Harvard Yard or taking the tour is free, some of the museums do have an admission charge, but it is generally very reasonable.  There is limited on-street metered parking available, but a few parking lots are in close proximity.  However, if possible, you are better off going by public transportation, which will give you more freedom to take your time, wander the campus, and enjoy all that Harvard University has to offer.

title: Skip the tour
text:
Ok, Ok, the tour is free.  You sign in at the tour center across the street from the campus and you're shown, oh, about three buildings and told the usual anecdotes.
But do you learn anything interesting?  Not if you have a tour book or access to the Internet.
We did learn, however, about the tour guide's roommates.  And why she came to Harvard.  And what her major is.  And that Lady Gaga has visited.  Oh, and that George Washington kept some of his troops there during the *civil* war.

title: Interesting Campus
text:
We visited here with a tour group on 4/6/15.

Unless you have a tour guide (which we did) to point out some of the historical buildings and share stories of their significance, there is not much to really see on the Harvard campus.

The history is definitely interesting, but for the average sightseer there is not much to it.

title: Beautiful campus in the heart of Cambridge
text:
My son is college shopping.  We had visited Tufts the day before, and while that campus was lovely, it has nothing on the history and tradition of the Harvard grounds.  Beautiful quads, scattered across a walkable distance, old buildings mixed with new, the great student vibe - you couldn't ask for a better day out.

The only drawback was the hugely rude man at the visitor's center.

title: Take the Free Tour!
text: The free hour long student lead tour is a MUST!  Visiting the campus is a treat but learning the historical context and modern uses of the buildings makes the experience far more enjoyable.  The Visitor's Center is across the street from Harvard Yard and the students working there are helpful and friendly.  Our two sons, 8 and 10 years old, were entertained as well!  We could hear them sharing the details of the tour with their grandmother over the phone that evening.  Don't miss out on this opportunity to enjoy Harvard's history!

title: Memorial Hall/Sanders Theater is Handsome but Also Deeply Touching
text:
We have been attending concerts at Sanders for 45 years; it is our favorite intimate concert hall in Boston. Its major negative is the discomfort of the too shallow/ crowded bench seating, (and the [basement level] bathrooms are reached down long steep stairways) but the rich beauty of the interior design, wood panelling and the stained glass windows and carved quotes, along with the warm clear acoustics, easily offset the discomfort. 
What never ceases to move me is in the high vaulted space of the lobby. Memorial Hall was indeed built as a memorial- to all the Harvard boys who died in the Civil War. When you read the marble plaques that line the walls,with their names and the places where they died,  you really do realize the sadness of that War- that was so essential to forming the country that we have become. It always makes me stop and reflect, and appreciate the sacrifice of such young boys. 

Memorial Hall was designed by the very famous Victorian architects, Ware and Van Brunt, and within a block of it are many other famous buildings. The modern School of Architecture and Landscape Design is right across the street, designed by local architect, Graham Gund. Just down the street is the Carpenter Center of Visual Arts, the only American building designed by le Corbusier. And more examples abound throughout the campus.

What never ceases to move me is in the high vaulted space of the lobby. Memorial Hall was indeed built as a memorial- to all the Harvard boys who died in the Civil War. When you read the marble plaques that line the walls,with their names and the places where they died,  you really do realize the sadness of that War- that was so essential to forming the country that we have become. It always makes me stop and reflect, and appreciate the sacrifice of such young boys. 

Memorial Hall was designed by the very famous Victorian architects, Ware and Van Brunt, and within a block of it are many other famous buildings. The modern School of Architecture and Landscape Design is right across the street, designed by local architect, Graham Gund. Just down the street is the Carpenter Center of Visual Arts, the only American building designed by le Corbusier. And more examples abound throughout the campus.

What never ceases move high vaulted space lobby. Memorial Hall indeed built memorial- Harvard boys died Civil War. When read marble plaques line walls, names places died, really realize sadness War- essential forming country become. It always makes stop reflect, appreciate sacrifice young boys. Memorial Hall designed famous Victorian architects, Ware Van Brunt, within block many famous buildings. The modern School Architecture Landscape Design right across street, designed local architect, Graham Gund. Just street Carpenter Center Visual Arts, American building designed le Corbusier. title: Is this what Ivy League looks like?
text: We took a group of top students to a Harvard invitational event. The representatives of Harvard were not welcoming. As a matter of fact, they were rude. There were no places for our students to sit. It was in the middle of a snowstorm and people were coming in and out of the building covered in snow. With no where to sit, our students had no choice but to sit--in their dress clothes--on the damp floor. There wasn't enough seating, enough food, or enough space for the number of students competing. None of the (dirty, seemingly forgotten) rooms were marked nor set up for our events. This was Harvard's chance to impress and inspire these high school students; instead, the students left wondering what all the hype is about. A very disappointing experience after working so hard to earn this trip.

title: Arts First
text: Check out Harvard's Arts Festival, usually held the first few days of May.  What an amazing experience!  Harvard students studying music, present dance, vocal, stage and instrumental performances in at least twelve different venues, including Harvard Yard, Memorial Church, and Sanders Theatre.  It's a feast for the senses, and an opportunity to visit historic buildings.  This all takes place in the middle of Harvard Square, the heart of Cambridge, MA.

text: For me, the fact that this instruction has been around since 1636 gives a since of wonderment on how many scholars had stood in the same I had. It is truly an institution of higher learning. I am visiting Boston and Harvard in a week. The snow that has fallen in recent weeks does not deter me one bit. This condition has been endured by others, which has results in their success ultimately. Go to Harvard university with a full day to take everything in, a half day is not enough in my opinion. title: Living History
text: Harvard Yard is the old center of activity. The paths were determined by where people walked, a brilliant method called "Lines of Desire" ‚Äî now accepted by landscape designers the world over. Two of the big brick dorms house POWs ‚Äî redcoats captured further north in the first winter of the war of independence. Many stories. Try to guess which of the people you see are future Masters of the Universe, and which are just wannabes like you and me.

title: Don't miss out when you are in Boston
text:
It was not a perfect day to visit as Boston got heavy rain and so cold but the campus made my day. It's an amazing place for me, glad to see the campus, students, church.. So much stories to learn and to tell. I spent a half day, walk from main campus, cross the bridge to Harvard Business School, one of my dream :). 
Don't forget to sign up the free tour, the main counter in front of the MRT station. Also grab some souvenir near by. I like the campus of HBS cos less people and very romantic, along the river.

title: Crimson Commons - Great Food
text: I spent a week attending a program here, stayiong on campus. All of our meals were at Crimson Commons and I must say it may be the best cafeteria food I have ever had. I have 7 meals here and all were very good. I appreciate the effort put into having quality food, especially since we were captive (pre-paid meal) customers which generally leads to lower quality.

title: Stunning University
text: We went there and as we got off the bus we were greeted by a man whose name i think was Dan. He was running the free Harvard tours that afternoon and he was fantastic. Being a past student, he knew everything about the history, architecture and past students of the college. The College itself is fantastic. Great architecture and very interesting to here what famous people had lived in which dorms. A must do when coming to Boston.

title: Historic and Cinematic
text:
It was a great tour of Harvard by my colleague who teaches there. It's surprising how much I recognised from watching so many American films that have used it as a location.

American history isn't a long affair, but at a place like Harvard you get a sense of it, even on a chilly December day.

Really great experience.

title: Worth a walk through
text: This is an American institution and it's definitely worth a walk through the Yard. Few of the educational buildings are open to the general public, but it's nice to see the architecture and soak up some history (or relive some of your favorites moments from books, memoirs, and movies). With Harvard Square nearby full of shopping and restaurants, this is a good place to come before or after a meal.

title: Probably the best place to see in Harvard - definitely worth a visit
text:
We took the Red Line transit from Boston to Harvard - less than 20 minutes from central Boston.

Harvard Yard is very close to the transit station and was the highlight of my visit to Harvard/Cambridge. Some lovely large old buildings and coloured chairs on the lawns. If you are there in the Fall/Autumn the trees are changing colour and offer some lovely picture opportunities. Obviously a place steeped in history and learning and we just wandered around by ourselves soaking up the atmosphere for half an hour or so.

It is well worth a visit and the best and most memorable part of my morning in Harvard. If you are visiting from Boston then we found a morning or afternoon was enough.

title: Breathtaking campus and excellent free tour!
text:
Visited Harvard on a recent trip to Boston. It was a short "T" trip via the red line, headed towards Alewife. The station name is "Harvard" and it brings you right to the famous Harvard Square. We joined a Student-Led Tour that departed from the Harvard Information Center, in the Smith Campus Center.

It was a walking tour of adult tourists not students. Our student leader was Jimmy. He was very familiar with the campus history, facts and details of the buildings interjected with lots of personal antidotes. Very enjoyable, personable and interesting young man.

We enjoyed the wonderful warm fall day and toured the following: Harvard Yard, Freshman dorms, Tercentenacy Theater, Widener Library, Memorial Hall, a Science centre, the John Harvard Statue and more. We did not enter any of the buildings except for the Memorial Hall. The building are amazing...red brick, some 300 years old. There are mature trees and wonderful roof lines to admire as well as steeples and grassy slopes. The architecture was striking...with a mix of traditional striped roofs and modern glass buildings from the 1070s.

After completing the tour we ambled around the campus to look at the Harvard Lampoon building. A quirky building with a smiling mouth and eyes. We recommend wandering the campus and enjoying all the free statues and the heritage buildings with their dormer windows. Breathtakingly Beautiful!

If you have time and the weather is fair, I recommend a short walk along the Charles River for a look at the buildings and bridges

Being tourists, we also stopped into the Coop store for some retail therapy. Lots of Harvard souvenirs to be purchased!

The campus is well worth an afternoon of touring! Apparently there are 100 plus iron gates...we only saw a few, maybe next time!

title: Enjoyed our tour with a non-quintessential student at Harvard
text: We did the formal information session followed by the tour of Harvard because my son is considering attending there.  The student who guided us was quite delightful and did not fit my image of a typical Harvard student at all.  I was particularly impressed with the way she talked about the dorm living there and how students are matched with roommates.  I could almost picture the "sorting hat" from Harry Potter, calling out the names of the students and which house they would be placed in for that year.

title: Wow! Who knew there was a 'John Harvard''?!
text: We came to the Harvard-Yale football game and made a point to walk Harvard Yard during pre-game festivities. I knew Harvard was older (1633) than our country, but we're never told about John Harvard.  Fortunately his statue draws a crowd in the Yard and we came across it.  Glad to know more about the founding father of this fine academic institution!

title: Spectacular Experience
text: Was at Harvard for a meeting and got a guided tour of Harvard University. Was fascinating to see the famous University and learn more about its history and what makes it unique. Was able to rub the famous shoe for good luck at the statue although I was pleasantly surprised to learn that the statue is actually not for Harvard and that it was not Harvard who founded this famous University. Spectacular place to be.

title: Some really interesting sites
text: If you get a chance to go to Cambridge (small city (town?)) across the river from Boston, stroll the downtown area and tour Harvard. After your tour, stroll the charming shops of Harvard Square.

title: I Recommend Self-Guided Harvard Yard Tour on Mobile App
text:
We went to Harvard on a drizzling day and without knowing better, joined the free (you pay tips) student-run tour departing from the student center. After 10 minutes we had to leave the tour - while it's pretty interesting to hear the world-leading uni's story from an actual Harvard student, her voice was totally overwhelmed by the rain and I could hardly hear her in a 30-strong crowd. 

I ended up downloading the free Harvard Yard tour app on my iPhone and did my own exploration. The app depends on Internet access to function but throughout the Harvard Yard you should be able to access the free (albeit slow) uni guest wifi access. The app does a pretty good job at providing historical and sometimes humorous perspective on the famous university. 

Overall I enjoyed the visit to the university - but I am a nerd and being in Harvard was half the enjoyment itself. If "one of the world's best universities" does not interest you on itself, you may not find the Harvard Yard interesting. Most buildings are off limit so all you could see is really just the facade of the buildings, and this may not be all that interesting if you belong to the "sightseeing tourist" category.

The app depends on Internet access to function but throughout the Harvard Yard you should be able to access the free (albeit slow) uni guest wifi access. The app does a pretty good job at providing historical and sometimes humorous perspective on the famous university. 

Overall I enjoyed the visit to the university - but I am a nerd and being in Harvard was half the enjoyment itself. If "one of the world's best universities" does not interest you on itself, you may not find the Harvard Yard interesting. Most buildings are off limit so all you could see is really just the facade of the buildings, and this may not be all that interesting if you belong to the "sightseeing tourist" category.

I ended downloading free Harvard Yard tour app iPhone exploration. The app depends Internet access function throughout Harvard Yard able access free( albeit slow) uni guest wifi access. The app pretty good job providing historical sometimes humorous perspective famous university. Overall I enjoyed visit university- I nerd Harvard half enjoyment. If`` one world's best universities'' interest, may find Harvard Yard interesting. Most buildings limit could see really facade buildings, may interesting belong`` sightseeing tourist'' category.

title: That is the teaching and learning edifice, I've heard most about, so far !
text:
And now as the final point and one of the most precious moments, that happened to us during our short visit to Boston, I must mention the glorious site of the Harvard University in Cambridge.
This beautiful town Cambridge across the River Charles, off the Boston, counts for its own as the city ,though one could assume that it is one extension of the main city of the Massachusetts.
Here, whole campus with grounds ,yards, gorgeous buildings of different fields of the science, the monuments of the most deserved men throughout the history of the Harvard are at the reach of us, the visitors, the tourists. Like for instance, the sitting statue of the first  Harvard benefactor, John Harvard ,who was also the alumnus of the University of Cambridge. After his decease ,the name of Harvard College was honored to the existant institution of Cambridge University.
That was in the 1636, the year of Harvard University establishment.
We enjoyed at the times to walk on these green yards and around the buildings, perceiving this splendid architecture of the edifices, acknowledging the great University history and also getting acquainted with the nowadays life of that grand Campus.
We saw within these grounds, the greatest library in the world, the Widener Library.
Some sculptures of the renown sculptors as Henry Moore adorn the Harvard University gardens.
That is outstanding place to be seen for all the times.

title: Living History Since 1636
text: Even if you‚Äôre not a student here, the Yard speaks its history to you as you walk around.  Take a tour, or not, it doesn‚Äôt matter.  Sit on one of the terrific, colorful metal chairs everywhere and drink in the uninterrupted centuries passed under these same trees by young people going back so far that George Washington kicked out a dorm full of them in order to quarter his troops during the Revolutionary War.  It‚Äôs amazing, really, and it‚Äôs all free.

text: Take a tour with the Harvard student - led group (free!) by registering in the Harvard information center in Harvard Square. title: Great Area. Lively. Football Game Fun
text:
What an awesome area. Very lively and fun. Lot to see.  Took in a  Harvard football game which was actually pretty good.  They're on a roll so the game was fun to watch. 

The historic stadium looks as such and bring a cushion to sit on. The entire Harvard Stadium is one big block on concrete.  It's a great place to watch a football game. Easy in and out.  Site lines great  and as a season ticket holder for the NY football Giants I had a better experience here than I ever do in that billion dollar dump of a football stadium in the swamp called Metlife Stadium.

title: Ivy League
text:
So glad we went here. There are free tours given by students and although our paper guide said they would not be running at the time we arrived about 3 pm, we latched onto a tour which had just started. A really fascinating place, the students were back and at work or play. Our guide was very informative and answered lots of questions. She had some great anecdotes about the place and it made us both wish we could relive our university years at Harvard, even hough we are both over 60.
Well worth a visit.

title: Very interesting - but not free!
text:
Firstly, Francesca, our tour guide was great.  She is a sophomore studying Astro-physics and a lovely, vibrant young lady.  Her style was efficient and humourous and just what you would expect from a tour guide.

We were under the impression that the tour was free but was suprised to learn that there was a cost of $10pp - what the?  We thought this was a bit pricey for a tour that lasted 40mins and  just toured the grounds - it didn't go into any buildings.  That being said, the tour was interesting and the grounds beautiful.

title: Harvard is a Great Place to Visit
text: Harvard University is a great place to visit. Begin in Harvard Square (which is very interesting in itself) and go right through the gate into Harvard Yard. Check out the buildings, students and scene as you walk around and take a selfie at John Harvard's statue. Continue your walk though the far side gate onto Quincy Street and turn left. The Harvard Art Museum is on this street. Cross Broadway and continue on Quincy Street, the large church looking structure on the left is Sanders Theater. Turn right onto Kirkland and left onto Divinity and wander around (or go into) the museums of Archaeology, Natural History & Zoology. Meander over to Oxford Street and back to Harvard Yard or Harvard Square.

The Harvard Art Museum is on this street. Cross Broadway and continue on Quincy Street, the large church looking structure on the left is Sanders Theater. Turn right onto Kirkland and left onto Divinity and wander around (or go into) the museums of Archaeology, Natural History & Zoology. Meander over to Oxford Street and back to Harvard Yard or Harvard Square.

title: A beautiful campus seen through eyes of a student guide!
text:
One of our son's friends, gave us a personal tour of "his school", and we had such a lovely afternoon.  It is a beautiful campus, with the red brick buildings, beautiful old trees, and many walking pathways to discover between the buildings.  There are many eateries, shops, and services available to student, professor, and tourist around the perimeter of the campus.

Walking over the bridge and watch the rowers go by is a great way to spend a few minutes and soak in the view of the school.  It is a beautiful place of learning.

title: Harvard University - Interesting to visit, great for pictures, not so much "to do"
text:
Easy to get to, we decided to visit Harvard with some time to kill in Boston. It was a great diversion, as it is a beautiful campus with some very nice sights. There are lots of places to get some nice photos, and the area around the campus is a typical college-type atmosphere.

We did not take a formal tour, instead opting for just walking around campus. We hit the area right outside the "T", and started walking. The buildings are beautiful, the campus well taken care of, and the students seem quite pleasant - given there are tourists plowing around.

There are tons of restaurants and other shopping conveniences around the campus, so take your time and enjoy the ambiance.

text: This tour give you a fascinating look at life at Harvard University. title: Best in class
text:
Harvard University and it's environs represents the pinnacle of meritocracy in education. It's unparalleled reputation and literal "Town & Gown" interaction creates an ethereal spiritualization of freedom of thought that both the ancient Greeks as well as our Founding Fathers imagined. As an alumnus, every time that I return to campus, I take away an endearing desire to utilize the opportunities that the Harvard relationship provides me and to be a better citizen to society as its result.
I love to share my experiences (literally) with friends, which I did last week. By the texts I received afterwards, I think that I succeeded!

title: If you only visit one university ...
text: Easily accessible by train, this part of Boston (Cambridge) is worth a visit. This is the US equivalent of Oxford or Cambridge - communities which have developed around a university. It is possible to just go for a wander, win the help of a map, or to join a tour guided by a Harvard student. These are promoted at the station exit. Look out for the statue of the three lies - a  fascinating example of not letting the truth get in the way of a good story. The range of authentic Harvard-branded goods on sale in the Coop is massive, if this is what you want. There are lots of eating options in the area as well. This is a great way to occupy half a day.

title: Famous Harvard University
text: We took a student lead tour of this historic university, which was free. You can grab your free tickets (for a specific timed tour) from Harvard Information Centre across the gates into Harvard on Massachusetts Avenue. The girl we had, had just  graduated from Harvard and this was her last tour. She did a great job of providing us with the history of Harvard. Explained what the buildings were used for, what life was like at this university. It made the tour very informative and personal for us. The campus itself was very beautiful, the architecture of the buildings was just stunning. And the tree lined grounds making it a wonderful place to study or just relax after class. We had a great time visiting and the surrounding area is also very nice to visit. There's plenty of caf√©s around to enjoy a coffee afterwards.

title: Students Everywhere On "Moving In" Weekend
text:
A really lovely, leafy, place with a collection of superb buildings.
Take some time to stop and stare at the world's best (ranked no.1 in 2013/14) university. See John Harvards' statue and remember that the ¬£500 bequest from this Southwark, London, publican's son is now worth $35Bn!

title: This is the Ivy League?
text: My friend and I were both highly disappointed by the Harvard Campus. Perhaps it's because of the way Hollywood makes it look in movies like Legally Blonde, but the old historical part of campus (Harvard Yard) is quite small. It's a pleasant space, no doubt. Chairs scattered across the lawn shaded by tall trees make for a nice place to stop and rest. However, the rest of campus is a vast expanse of nondescript brick buildings. Even the few free museums we went into failed to impress. The Semitic Museum's collection seemed to comprise solely replicas of famous artifacts, although it did have a lot of information on Cyprus, which I suppose impressed us. Boston if full of historical buildings and shady green spaces to wander around. Harvard didn't stand out from any of the others, and they don't require a long metro ride.

title: Inspiration for Youth of All Ages
text:
We took our kids for a tour of the campus and I think they enjoyed the tour, but getting an honest opinion about a site seeing adventure is like asking if they washed their hands before dinner.
 
Get used to the tour guides calling the it Hah-vard.  Although we weren't able to tour any of the buildings from the inside, viewing the historic architecture from the outside was a treat and I can only imagine the feeling of gratification of attending class there.  

The tour is well worth the donation and the guide was friendly and very informative.  I would definitely recommend the tour for children and adults of all ages.

title: It's Harvard!
text: What a gorgeous campus!  The architecture, the history...what can you say?  I made it a point to visit here on a vacation to Boston, and it didn't disappoint!  I may be in trouble, though...after seeing the campus, my daughter now wants to attend college there.  Heck, I want to go back and attend college here ;-)  It's definitely worth a stop if you're in the area.

title: Worth it for the architecture
text: We were lucky enough to hear an orientation being given so got a little extra history lesson, but if you have even a little bit of time, it's worth going here just for the architecture of the buildings alone.  The gardens are also very pretty.  In fact, the whole campus is very nice and peaceful (we were there early in the morning).  I must admit I wouldn't think walking around a college campus would make for a good attraction, but I found myself glad I did this one.

title: Bow to the temple of learning
text: The best time to visit Harvard University, Cambridge is towards the last week of May when a variety of Commencement functions are held at all the Schools. Weather-wise it is very welcoming, neither cold nor hot, of course, there might be occasional drizzles. Fresh intelligent faces are in all smiles because the exams are over and now it is party time. Some are perhaps little sad because the time has come to bid adieu to this wonderful place and their pals, join the real world and contribute to the welfare of mankind. It is a common sight to find youngsters with their parents and siblings who have come from long distances just to be with the graduating wonder in this joyous occasion. They proudly sport caps, t-shirts, jackets etc with logo of Harvard Dad/Mom/ Brother et al. The shopkeepers first congratulate them before doing the business. Service staff in restaurants, many of whom are students themselves, welcome these guests with words which come from their deep within. Cabbies entertain with all kinds of questions. Even the Police, who usually maintain a stony countenance, are a smiling lot. Joy is all-pervasive; it is beyond description. You have to be there to get a real feel of it.

title: Dramatic and impressive
text:
We stepped out of the subway and were then in the University grounds.  Lots of red brick, lots of large buildings, a dramatic library and lots of student-y atmosphere.  

We didn't feel the need to do a tour, we saw enough just walking around, and got a good sense of things. There is money here.

It's not possible to do a drive through, and parking in Harvard looked difficult, so we felt we did the right thing to go on the subway.

Lots of good touristy things to do nearby, great place to see with much significance.  All this and MIT too!

title: A very nice choice for a half day visit
text: Harvard University is located in the Cambridge area of Boston and is very easily accessible with the underground. We spend there a little more than a half day and it definately worthed it. The campus is green and well maintained and there's always people walking around. There are several historical buildings that you can visit and also a handful of nice museums. We visited the museum of natural history which was very interesting and holds an outstanding collection of flowers made of glass. We also had the chance to follow a free guided tour of the university held by a student which was very nice and informative.

title: Not really what I was expecting
text: To be fair, when we decided to go to Harvard, we didn't allow ourselves enough time to get out of the car and walk the grounds properly, not did we do a proper tour, so that is definitely skewing my review. We decided to drive around the grounds to see the buildings and try and get a feel for the campus. Well, the campus is huge and with all of the construction going on it was difficult to do a proper "drive-thru." The buildings we did see were old and impressive, but not really the WOW factor I was expecting. Wish we had given ourselves more time to see what we were maybe missing.

title: Awesome campus and friendly staff
text: Harvard's campus is a great place to walk around. A lot of history here. Plenty of trees and shade to walk around in and enjoy the grounds. Shops and restaurants of Harvard Square are right outside the gate. Staff is very friendly. Met a very friendly security guard originally from Pakistan (sorry, don't remember his name), who was very helpful and went out of his way to provide directions. (Thank you!)

title: Take the student guided tour; informative, interesting and fun.
text: We had been advised that student tours of the campus were free but apparently this is only the case from September and not during the summer vacation.  In any event we purchased our tickets, $10, at Out of Town News kiosk just a short walk from the metro station, and were soon off on a guided tour of the campus with Eli, a delightful and entertaining student going into his junior year.  The tour was just over an hour long but it was Eli that made it interesting and informative; he focussed on the history of Harvard - including the buildings, architecture and statues - Harvard traditions and some of the famous people who have attended Harvard.  He was a great story teller and wove in his personal experience of this great University.  He was also very patient and was very happy to answer a range of questions including one or two from some pretty precocious little kids! Highly recommend doing the tour and hope you have as good a guide as Eli!

title: Now I can say I "went to" Harvard (last weekend)...
text: Harvard is probably my favorite area in Boston, lots of interesting architectures, not your typical college town (probably more of a fancy college town since I don't believe many of those stores will survive in a poor college town).  We also joined the tour, it was funny and enjoyable. The museum of natural histroy has a lot to see.  We had lunch with food prepared by food truck "Bon Me" on campus. The wheelchair accessibility is slightly better than the rest of Boston.

title: Free Harvard Tour
text: Free tours are offered by students (tip afterward if guide did a good job). Meet in the information store which is across the street in the large building, next door to the student clothing store. The tour does provide some interesting historical  information about Harvard and also some of those traditional tales stated over the years.  The tour is slanted more for families who have students that will be attending Harvard and although our son-in-law is attending there, he is a Masters student and obviously independent. Therefore, when conversation about housing and finance began, we had to be patient in order to continue on with the tour.

title: Worth a walk to soak up history and boost the IQ.
text: The older part of Harvard Yard reeks history, tradition and has done a great deal to shape US and world history by serving as a place of learning for generations of leaders.  Hard not to feel the historic aspect as you stroll around and through the gates.  Cambridge is well worth a visit.  Visiting Harvard and MIT is a great thing to do with young teens to help motivate them to be aspirational in their academic and life goals.

title: So?
text: Interesting. No, not the Harvard Yard. But some people who give a good rating to this place on Tripadvisor. They left a comment like, "I finally made it!" Psshh. Yes this place is historical and can be seen as "amazing," but really - reality is..Harvard Yard is so crowded by tourists,visitors, and students by day. Students don't mind throwing dirty looks to random passengers often times, Camera flashes everywhere, limited footpaths, and it is a very very small yard overall. Not impressed.

title: I have to agree with the "average" reviewers
text: If you haven't seen it, then you have to visit. Just be aware that just looking at the buildings isn't that great. It's really not that picturesque a school. Buildings are very old, and guess what, they look very old. Take a tour to get some insight, or visit the museums, etc. Lots of tourists wandering through, so lots of unfriendly people. Probably ticks off the students too, who seem to be typically uncaring to others, drifting through their millennial world. Surrounding area, Harvard Square, busily annoying.

title: Very interesting and worth the time
text: Our tour guide Laura did a great job.  As a student attending the university she was able to give a first hand experience of the school. Although the tours are free of charge they only permit 35 people per tour.  We got there ~ 0950 and the 1000 tour was full.  You can get tickets an hour before the next tour.  So we waited around till 1000 and got the tickets for the 1100 tour, and then went walking around the area.  The office gets congested as people are either waiting for the tour to begin or waiting to get tickets.  Parking in the area is dear.  It cost us $29 to park for the short time we were there.

Maybe I am not that kind of person who is so into how a university was from.

title: Okay, Not Awesome
text: We did a self guided tour using their Yardtour app. If you are in the area it is definitely worth a visit, but if you are short on time, you can skip it. There isn't that much to "see"-  I found Yale prettier - but you may want to go just because it is Harvard.

title: Great tour and very interesting
text:
The grounds are spectacular and the buildings steeped in history.
We decided to take the tour guided by one of the students.  Very interesting as you also caught glimpses of the school from his perspective.  
Interesting to find out also that he was lucky enough to be here on scholarship (although I don't think they call it that) but basically not at any cost to him.  Of course he must have been an exceptionally bright fellow as only  a small percentage of applicants get accepted.
Very enjoyable-glad we did it.

title: Harvard. You should visit but it is nothing that special.
text: I live in a town with an old urban university, not as old as Harvard, but old none the less.  Harvard was fun to visit and the buildings are interesting but in the end it is not hugely special. Chalk it up as something you should do when travelling to Boston but you only need 3 to 4 hours. Note that there is expensive meter parking and different blocks have different maximum times. The maximum of the maximums is 2 hours. There are garages but you can take the subway right into to Harvard Square.

title: Great Tour
text: We decided to visit Harvard University & glad we did. We took the red line subway from our hotel. We were staying in Beacon Hill section & had a pleasant 10 min ride to the Harvard station. As you exit the train station to your right is a tour for $10 given by Harvard students. The tours start at 10:30 & run until 3:30 every half hour. Our tour guide, Francesca, was very informative, interacted with the group, and had a lot of information to share. The tour lasts about an hour & is held outside. The area around Harvard had plenty of shopping & restaurants as well.

title: It's Harvard.....
text: Took the Subway to Harvard and well what can one say.. It was Harvard.  A must see if you are in Boston simply because it is the oldest university,the alumni, and the famous people that started there and then left.. The libraries are amazing.  It is all Red as we learned that the color is Crimson in memory of the blood shed during the Revolutionary War.  We did not take a guided tour but walked the campus.  Great architecture and plenty of shops and places to eat.

title: horribly disappointing
text: As a university student, I could not have been more disappointed in the Harvard campus. It lacked flow, the paths seemed to randomly go in any direction, other than three buildings, the rest looked the same, a very plain red brick. Not impressed at all. As the oldest school in America I would've expected a lot more to come from the grounds. Overall, not worth the trip up to Cambridge to visit the campus, you're really not missing out on much.

title: Beautiful historic University
text:
We walked through the grounds of Harvard University when we went to brunch at the Sheraton Commander Hotel.  We were amazed at how beautiful the university grounds are.  

Some of the architecture is spectacular and the grounds are really pretty.  Having only seen the universities in Sydney and some of the regional NSW universities back home, none of the Australian campuses compare to the history of Harvard.

title: Finally saw Harvard
text: Visited friend on Broadway in Cambridge. A short walk up Broadway past exquisite old New England Victorian Colonial homes, each bigger and more unique than the last, if that is possible, to arrive at Harvard itself. FInally took the time to wander the campus with its trees and unique buildings. What a pleasure.

title: Quick relaxing stroll around the campus
text: We passed through Boston on our way to Niagara Falls and took a quick break at Harvard U. It took us quite a while to find a parking and to find the entrance to the campus. The campus was quiet and peaceful. We were there in late afternoon and the wind was very cool. It was quite a relaxing stroll around. Too bad we don't have someone who was familiar with the place to tour us around.

title: Do not rub the foot of John Harvard statue...
text:
(5) ... because this statue is frequently peed upon for good luck. It is also not John Harvard - no one knows how he looked.

(4) do take a photo at the steps of the Widener Library. It is a memorial to Harry Widener, who perished with the Titanic in 1912. Harry has a study room inside, and a desk with  a vase replenished with fresh flowers every day. The library has 50 miles of shelves and Harvard students aim to make out among the shelves once before graduating.

(3) do visit Harvard Yard during Winter - the snowmen outside the freshmen halls range from Easter Island statue lookalikes to Picasso-esque women.

(2) do enjoy Harvard Yard on a Sunday morning - the bells of Memorial Church ring first, then near to noon, the bells of Lowell Hall chime fantastically for about an hour. In between there is quiet and beauty, birds, squirrels and rabbits.

(1) do visit on Moving- in Day (end Aug). See the freshmen from all over the US and the world move in to the freshmen halls which surround The Yard. There is a festive air. Student advisors are on hand to tell visitors all about Harvard and various groups give out Harvard memorabilia, chilled lemonade and brochures.

title: Worth a quick train ride to Cambridge
text: We wanted to see Cambridge and why not start at Harvard?  It was move in day for summer school, so it was fun to see all the students and their parents.  Made us realize that Harvard students aren't that different from the rest of us - all of them have that deer in headlights look the first day.  The campus was beautiful and we enjoyed looking at all the buildings.  It was easy to get to via the metro and worth an hour or so on a nice afternoon.

title: Escorted tour of campus - Harvard university
text:
The tour guides are located in the main square in Cambridge MA and for 10# per head, small groups are given a tour of Harvard University campus.
Our guide on May 29th was Eli - a student who was knowledgeable and amusing. A visit on our own would have been very superficial so we feel the money was well spend and made an enjoyable afternoon.

title: Harvard, an amazing place
text: Any trip to Boston is not complete without a trip across the Charles River to Harvard University. The school is historic and amazing, but the quaint area of Cambridge is a joy as well. We enjoy discovering new restaurants and sites each time we return to visit our daughter who is a student at Harvard.

text: I'm not sure what I expected, but what we found on a Sunday afternoon was a cool place with laid back people content to do their own thing. Great little shops around, I suggest the dessert shop Finale, it was Wiked Pissah.

title: Food Carts & Historic Campus
text:
Try and time your trip here to include lunch at the food trucks so you can take in the activity of campus life. There were three food options when I visited, and I believe all accepted both credit cards and cash (though you don't get a receipt, so if you're there for work make sure you use the email receipt option. Campus is beautiful and there are many colorful chairs in the open yard space, if you don't want to lounge in the grass and eat lunch, which is something I highly recommend. 

I didn't take the tour, but enjoyed wondering around campus. I'm at another ivy league school, so beautiful old building's and history are something I'm used to, but it was still well worth the trip up to Cambridge!

title: You can always say you went to Harvard
text:
A trip to Greater Boston isn't really complete without visiting one of the most famous universities in the world. Particularly if you're from the western part of North America, the age of some of the  the buildings alone will keep you interested. (Harvard was founded in 1636) We wandered down the hallways of one of the older buildings, and overheard a student being examined by a panel of professors - in Latin. There are several good places on campus and nearby to grab some good souvenirs like the requisite t-shirt or hoodie. 
A tip: if you want the true student experience, schedule your visit over lunch, and eat in the freshmen's cafeteria. Online reviews of the food rate it as good/not great. These are obviously people who haven't gone to school elsewhere; by cafeteria standards it's above par. The attraction is the room itself, called the Memorial Hall, built to honor the Harvard Alumni who perished during the American Civil War in defence of the Union. It's quite the building, and the meal is reasonably priced.

title: Students/Academics can access libraries if you come prepared
text:
Harvard is a beautiful campus to wander with its historic buildings and spacious grounds. 

As a foreign PhD students and university lecturer it is possible to gain access to the many libraries as a "visiting researcher" - I took a simple letter from my university and with my passport was able to get free 3 month access to both the standard libraries and the Special Collections from the Library Privileges Office. Even for just a 2 day visit it was great to be able to go inside and see the immense collections, as well as read some 400+ year old books that I have not been able to find copies of at home.

title: Harvard -- Nothing More Needs to be Said!!!
text: My wife and I visited Harvard where our son is in his second year at Harvard Law School.  The campus is historic, not only as one of the oldest universities in America, but also because of the many notable people who have attended Harvard, including President John F. Kennedy.  Harvard Square, which is the open space at the center of the university, offers a quiet place to reflect on your visit to Harvard.

title: Such history!
text:
We took in several museums (we especially liked the natural history museum, and the display of historic scientific instruments in the Science Center) and enjoyed walking around on our own.  

We also did an information session and tour.  The information session was in Sanders Theatre, which is a beautiful building.  The tour was led by 2 current students, and they gave us a good perspective on the House system and other aspects of the university.

text: Wandering around Harvard's historic campus is very relaxing...(unless you are a student stressing out because of exams, of course). title: Not much to see
text: I didn't get a chance to visit any of the Harvard Museums but the campus itself looks like any other part of New England: brick buildings with white roof and trimmings around quaint grassy courtyards and squares. The free tour is a waste of time: you go nowhere that is not already publicly accessible and learn nothing you don't get from signs or guidebooks. It was nice to visit such a famous place and to see the John Harvard statue but it is a stop in Boston that can easily be skipped.

title: OK, I was a grad student there for 6 years and my son was just accepted!
text: I loved living at Harvard as a tutor at Lowell House and studying there in the Archaeology wing. I will agree with many others that it is the top university in the world. Just as I enjoyed visiting Cambridge University in England many years ago, I would say that anyone visiting Boston should visit Harvard. I have photographed the sights of Harvard in all seasons, but I enjoyed the snow on the elaborate wrought iron fences around the yard the most. The Head of the Charles Regatta is an opportunity for a brilliant cavalcade of color as the crews race on the Charles. A football game creates tail gating like you have never seen. I look forward to visiting my son as he starts his adventure at Harvard.

title: A must see!
text: Visiting Harvard was on my bucket-list. They have a visitors center that offers tours every hour on the hour. That was perfect! Our student tour guide was very knowledgeable and took us all across the campus. We learned quite a bit of history and information about the school and the community. Being from the south, Ivy League schools appear so distant and unobtainable, but the feel of the environment made you feel that anything is possible with hard work. I'd definitely recommend the tour and recommend walking around Harvard Square. They have tons of shops and restaurants to visit. The T rail stops right at the front gate too. Also visit the student-ran book store too. They have way cheaper prices that others.

title: Really?  Why Bother?
text:
Maybe it's because I've lived near Harvard for 25 years.  Maybe it's because the institution has been coasting on its reputation for a century.  Maybe it's because I read one story after another in the local papers about its attempts to manipulate the community.  But there's not that much to see here.  Harvard's grounds are not that attractive -- not nearly so as any of a hundred campuses across the country.  One can listen to the stories of past notables.  Or one can consider the embarrassments of the current institution -- the B-School which helped drag down the economy, the Ed-School which has mucked up the system of public education in this country. 

Want to go for a place for a nice walk?  Try the Fresh Pond Reservoir, the Minuteman Bike Trial, the Charles River trails, or the Mt. Auburn Cemetery.  Wander around a bit at Harvard if you want to see some stodgy, rather unattractive buildings, but god help you if you spend money for a tour. Does Harvard need $10 to promote its mythology when it has a $30 billion endowment?  I think not.

title: Great walking tour of Harvard
text:
We completed a terrific tour of Harvard University.  Hannah a student at the uni was our tour guide and explained the history of the place and answered all questions with great expansion.  Some fantastic historical buildings throughout the grounds.  Good to see where 'Facebook' was created!!  If you do the Boston Duck tour, there is no additional fee for the tour.
Easy to get to via the subway and worth the trip if you have some time to spare in Boston.

title: Hahvahd Tour
text:
We shunned the free tour and opted for the Hahvahd Tour run by students - cost $10 per person and worth it too! Our tour guide Pryanka was excellent. She had a great insight into the history of the University and mixed fact with myth in a very entertaining way.

The free map provided with the tour points you into the excellent delights the surrounding streets have to offer. We happily spent a whole day in the area.

title: Take the free tour
text: We stopped in to see Harvard and were pleased to find out that the students union offers free tours of Harvard Yard. It gave us some of the history of the place. It was a very interesting way to spend the hour. For shopping go to the co-op for clothes and souvenirs. Their is a separate co-op that is an excellent bookstore. Try to stop in both stores.

title: It is Harvard...
text: America's oldest and arguably most famous university located just outside Boston Massachusetts has a cozy campus with a rich history.  The area is nice and quiet, but one would expect more from the campus.  Other campuses have more to offer visitors and I would imagine students and faculty.  I am a big fan of architecture and unique buildings, but there was not much to offer.  Maybe the university is steep in the tradition and history and keep true to that identity which I can appreciate.  I am sure if I spent more time in the area I would find the appeal, but first impressions leave with the overrated label.

text: The classically styled buildings offer a sensory experience of how it might be to spend study time here.  Harvard Yards is a great place for a stroll, or in summer, a sit on the grass.  Bustles with life even in winter, and the restaurants and cafes are minutes away if you need refreshers

title: I went to Harvard..
text:
Yes I went to Harvard for a visit!!  A walk through the Harvard Yard it well worth doing - we went in late October so the autumn colours added to the sense grandeur of this institution and the grounds.  Students were also on campus as it was term time and there was a sense of things happening when classes finished and students came out of the buildings and moved about the grounds to their next class.  If you have time visit the Memorial Church and stand in front of Widener Library & take in the enormity of this building and of course don't forget to touch the foot on the John Harvard Statue.
There is a walking tour which is conducted by students and is called Hahvahd Tour - it starts from just outside the Harvard T stop - if I had know about this before arriving I would have connected with this tour as it looked like it was fun and informative the couple of times I crossed paths with the tour group on my walk through the campus.  There is a small cost if you join a tour, but just walking through the campus grounds is free.

title: Visit the Yard
text: A slow walk through Harvard Yard may give you a sense of the quiet, peaceful, intensity of this college.  A visit in the autumn is probably best -- students walking to and from classes, and colored leaves on the many trees.  Rub the toe of John Harvard's boot for luck.  If you have time, arrange before your visit for a tour, guided by one of the current students -- they're knowledgeable, and funny.

title: Get the App!
text:
You need to download the app available via Itunes or Harvard's website.
If you are using Android, download the Boston city guide from Tripadvisor and you will find the Harvard Yard Tour and its great!
Free Wifi available on campus, makes your visit so much more enjoyable and interactive with all the Historic infomation you can find on the App.
Best way to get there is with the T red line, you get off right at Harvard Square. Walking along surrounding streets is also great, nice neighborhood and safe.

title: Harvard University
text: If ever there was a brand name in colleges, Harvard is it. The campus is well worth the visit from "Harvard Yard" where the freshmen are housed, to Widener Library, named after a victim of the Titanic, to Memorial Hall, the monument to Harvard men who died (on the Northern side) of the Civil War. The campus stretches along the Charles River with the beautiful Business School across from the Cambridge side. The Fogg Art Museum is closed right now, under renovation but the Peabody Museum of Natural History is open and filled with interesting things. The famous Glass Flowers are found there. Buildings by IM Pei and LeCorbusier can be found as well as those from early architects such as Henry Hobson Richardson. After the visit, wander the stores of Harvard Square and have lunch in one of the many restaurants.

title: Harvard yard --so lovely..
text:
if you plan to visit Cambridge, don't miss the Harvard Yard. Just to see young people walking around the paths, through beautiful trees and lawns to get to classes and the monumental Widener Library, is exhilarating.  Very easy to reach on the T (public transport.) Guided tours will tell you that the much visited statue of John harvard has nothing to do with the man ! it's charming all the same.
One can combine this visit with another at MIT, or with having a meal around Harvard Square. So time of visit can vary from one to four hours.

title: Must see on a visit to Boston and Cambridge
text:
If you go to Boston, you must go to Harvard University.  It is easily accessible by train, but we were driving and had no difficulties getting a park nearby.  I had been before with a tour, so this time we just wandered, and really enjoyed the experience.  Do some reading beforehand about John Harvard, the library which burnt down and the candle story, the massive library just to name a few, and you will appreciate it so much more.  

Full of history and amazing achievement, it is worth a visit for a few hours, and you can finish with a stop at the COOP where you can buy great memorabilia, and a reasonably priced coffee and sandwich at the cafe upstairs, as there isn't much choice in the food department downstairs on the Square.

title: Worth a visit
text: We were looking for a grand entrance to Harvard.  But we found only a small gate leading to the university.  It was a sunny fall day which made it very pleasant to visit the campus.  The Statue of John Harvard was a popular site for photography.  A mixture of old and new architectures in the campus.  Heard so much about it and well worth a visit while touring Boston.

title: Harvard Tour- Overall Disappointing
text:
We set out to compare both the Yale and Harvard campus tours within a couple days time. There are a few options for tours of Harvard but we elected the official tour provided by current students. This was apples to apples to the Yale tour we took. 

We were expecting much more from the Harvard tour. Unfortunately, it was rather boring as compared to the Yale tour. Perhaps it was the guide, but there were few fun, interesting historical stories. The tour was so dry, I think we would have had a better experience just roaming on our own. 

Harvard Yard is pretty with nice grassy areas and trees. It had colorful chairs in the center of the grass where students can hang out. There are a lot of historical buildings but the architecture isn't nearly as interesting as that of Yale. It was all just a little disappointing but we are glad we did it. Honestly, the campus is nothing special compared to many other campuses we have attended or explored. 

If we were students comparing the schools and taking the tours, we'd pick Yale hands down. 

Another note, there are no parking lots in the area. You have to use metered parking which is a max of 2 hours and accepts only quarters. If you plan on touring around, you will need to have quarters handy and be ready to make your way back to the meter a few times to add time.

title: Impressive
text: My girlfriend and I went on a self guided tour of Harvard University at around 10:00 p.m. on Thursday evening, October 3, 2013.  Fortunately, it was not raining.  I must say that it took a while to find parking at Harvard Square, even at this time of night.  In any case, we walked the campus for about an hour and could have easily got lost.  This university is spread out like a small city.  Of course, the buildings here have such architectural beauty.  What surprised me is that the students I spoke with for directions were all so polite.  One even went out of his way to let us into the Harvard Law School library using his student key card.  Apparently this library is open all the time  during school hours.  It was a pleasure to see one of America's finest universities firsthand.

title: What is great about America
text:
Just walking on the campus made us feel smarter, and proud.
Harvard University is how I always imagined- structured. Intellectual, momentous. It truly made me realize how wonderful our educational system could and should be.
The campus was buzzing with young, enthusiastic minds, the structures were statuesque, and the grounds beautiful.
The day we went it was cold and breezy. The leaves we're kicking around, which made the experience that much more surreal.

title: Institute of Higher learning
text: Harvard is very prestigious, both educationally and historically.  It offers opportunities in all professional fields to those who are willing to study hard and apply their skills in and out of this university.  I enjoyed the varied living and adaptive centers for all levels whether family or single.  Harvard offers many benefits for those who achieve a doctorates in their specified fields.

title: Excelent visit
text:
I highly recommend while visiting Boston to go see Harvard University. 
As you get off the subway you will see some students from HU are there to offer a free guide while telling some of their personal experiences. This is great. 
You can walk all around the campus and the outsides which are also beautiful. There is a little centre where you can have something to eat or buy Harvard merchandising products.
When you visit is finished i suggest you walk south by the river side right to the Boston University which is also very big and beautiful. The walk by the riverside is beautiful. !!

title: Hovering Harvard
text: We visited Boston via a cruise ship in mid-September and decided to take time to visit Harvard by the taking the T (metro) there.  The trip on the T was entertaining and an interest grabber for first timers in Boston - very easy to access and find your way about - also a lot less costly than taking a cruise ship excursion.  We loved walking through the grounds and while we didn't have time to take a guided tour we picked up on enough of the history to appreciate the surroundings.  The historic buildings emit an atmosphere of devotion to education and learning amid abounding stories of notable Americans.  We saw evidence of the Kennedys attendance here and a bit of nostalgia surrounding the era of the Kennedy family.  A stroll through the town-like streets was picturesque and low-key but enjoyable.  We visited the student run book store and bought a Harvard baseball hat for a relative - great little store.  Harvard is not a show-stopper but it is worthy of a visit just to say you've been there.

title: HAHVAHD
text: We went to get a T-shirt and it should have read, "My dad went to Harvard and all he got me was this crappy T-shirt." Yes, there are plenty of souvenir shops and tourists, but the tour provides an informative historical perspective. Easy access from Boston by cab or transit. Food and souvenirs are reasonably priced (you get a discount if you've taken the tour). Let's face it, most schools look like glorified prisons, but that doesn't mean you can't visit and have a good time.
