title: Interesting with a great student-led tour
text:
Took a $10 student-led tour of the Harvard yard and a couple of the neighbouring streets. Our (student) guide, Brie ("like the cheese") was anything but shy and probably born to do these kinds of tours; for more than an hour, she - despite a sour throat - constantly talked, explained, shared anecdotes and entertained our group. She had no written script and certainly wouldn't have needed one. She encouraged us to ask questions and did - as far as I can tell - a great job of answering them. All in all, this added a lot to our experience of Harvard and its history.

The Harvard yard itself (open and free of charge to visit) is rather impressing, with old buildings where lots of old presidents and other famous business people and celebrities have waked the corridors. Having been to Cambridge (England) and stayed in a college dorm room there for a short while, I was maybe not as hugely impressed with the Harvard campus as I otherwise would have been, yet it is indeed a place where it's well worth spending a few hours.

title: beautiful
text:
The campus is very beautiful. A lot of visitors. Widener Library is a must to visit, and it will be funny if you did some homework on the stories (some are fake) of this library. Drawback is the library is not open to public.

The Harvard statue is a statue of three lies. The inscriptions in the statue are all "fake". Do check this before visiting!

There are some restaurant outside the campus on Mass Ave. Chinese, italian, so on. The Harvard Coop store might be interesting to people who would like to take something about Harvard back home. Although they items are mostly overpriced, with a Harvard logo.

Harvard Museum of Natural History is my favorite site in the campus. There is an admission fee around $12 ($10 for students). It will take a whole day to take a through tour of it.

title: Incredible and Beautiful
text: We wandered around in awe as our daughter showed us her stomping grounds.  Simply said, this campus is astoundingly beautiful.  Leave yourself lots of time to explore the campus, it is huge.  And definitely take the student run tour.  They have a wealth of information at their fingertips.  Walk back in history as you learn how the school was started, and how Cambridge grew around this incredible institute of higher learning.  You won't be sorry you took the time to visit this incredible institution of higher learning.  If you have the opportunity, sit in on a class.  I feel like I learned more in one class at The Kennedy School than I did in four years of undergraduate work elsewhere.

title: Great student-led tour
text: If you're interested and have the time, I highly recommend taking the student-led tour of Harvard Square.  These students have memorized a ton of history about the college and devote some of their personal time to share it with you.  Also, be sure to take advantage of the walking time with the student if you have kids interested in attending - they can provide good insight into what it's really like...but don't forget to tip them if you enjoyed it - they are college students after all...

title: Slightly underwhelmed
text: I was very much looking forward to this visit having studied at Cambridge University, UK and spent a considerable amount of time at Oxford also I was expecting similar visual splendour. Although the buildings were very impressive I disappointingly I felt a little underwhelmed particularly the grounds appeared somewhat tired. Perhaps a reflection of a true working University maybe? Nevertheless, a pleasure to wander around one of the premier institutes of academia in the world.

title: Over scripted with very little real life information - Student Harver tour
text:
We did the student Havard tour while visiting Cambridge. It was $10 per person for a 1 hour guided tour through a small part of Harvard university as the university is very spread out.
Our guide was a student of Harvard. It was overall a disappointing tour. The guide stuck to her script (even closed her eyes when reciting it back to us) and the humour was really poor and much too scripted. The guide also was required to walk backwards which was very disconcerting and I felt that I had to watch out for her in case she would walk into something/someone.
We didn't actually get much of an insight into student harvard life nor were we told a lot about some of the more famous people who would have passed through the university.
I think the organisers of this tour should do a little bit of investigation into how other historical universities carry out their tours. My husband was on the Trinity College tour in Dublin a couple of weeks later and even though it was only 30 mins long he thought it was far superiour to the Harvard Tour and the guide was excellent.

text: We were able to go around this famous institution, and it gives a nostalgic feeling.  Parking around the university was a nightmare, however. text:

At night, we bought pizza at Otto's pizza and sat at the yard. The lawn chairs were inviting me and my family to enjoy a beautiful night under the starts and quietness of the yard.

title: Fun and informative Cambridge Historical Tour
text: The hour went too quickly. Walked through the Harvard campus with a costumed guide from Cambridge Historical Tours.  "Henrietta" had been an astronomer at Harvard (true story) in the late 1800's.  Started the tour at Harvard Square information booth across from the Coop.  Great stories about campus pranks e.g. Crimson vs. Lampoon.  Interesting info about John Harvard, Widener Library, some of the Harvard Yard Gates for example.   It was the highlight of our trip to Cambridge.

title: Busy area, despite the school break
text:
As part of our Harvard tour, the yard was a major part! Again this seems to be the central area for students as all the dorms are all around including the huge library. Depsite the fact that this was summer break, it was still fairly busy. There were several other tours coming and going, 
I can only begin to imagine how crowded this would be when school is in full swing.

title: Walking in Footsteps
text: Recently toured a small portion of Harvard. It wasn't until I looked at the map of Harvard that I realized how large this campus is and how it has expanded over the years. The history, alone is enough to justify a quick viewing. Our tour guide gave us a brief history about how the dormitory's are named, including the naming of the Library. The "3 Lies" of the statue of John Harvard. I would suggest getting a tour from someone. Just wandering around, is only part of the story, without an informed guide to tell you all the little things, you will miss out!

title: A Must Visit
text:
Harvard may be an almost untouchable university for most people as far as acceptances go, but who says you can't enjoy the gorgeous campus of the first university in the United States. 

We enjoyed an entire evening chilling and strolling around the oldest part of the university. You can sit around on the chairs, or have picnics on the lawn. 

My kids ran around and enjoyed some of the artifacts and statues that are placed all over the place. 

I'm a big fan of visiting Universities, and this one has been one of my favorite ones so far. And maybe the scholarly atmosphere rubbed off on my kids too.

title: Student tour was great
text: We got a great tour from a Harvard student for only $10.  They are standing around at the train station exit with maps to give away for free even if you don't want to do the tour.  We had only a short time there so it was great to hear the history of Harvard with all the funny insider information that you aren't going to get by wandering around.  There are no buildings open to the public, so it is an outdoor tour, but still well worth it in my opinion.  I don't blame them for keeping their buildings closed to the public.  Make sure you hear the Conan O'Brien story!

text: After visiting the campus, I had to research WHY everyone wanted to touch the left foot of the John Harvard statue.  It was what I expected...just for luck! title: Save your time for something better
text:
As I am an academician, universities are always in my to do list. I was very excited about my Boston trip because I would be able to see Harvard, MIT and Boston University. Unfortunately, I spared two hours of my short trip to Harvard University and If I knew I could not enter any of the buildings (not even the library) I would not come to Harvard. 
If you want to see some old buildings, just walk through Boston downtown. It does not worth the long T trip. All buildings were locked, art museum was closed until Fall 2014, the library did not issue me a day pass because i did not bring a letter from my advisor (I am a PhD student and this is the most ridiculous practice I have ever seen. All researchers are welcome in my university's library, and I could enter all libraries across the country with my university ID but Harvard is an exception). 
Do you want to learn the history of the university? Read it. Buildings do not have informative signs, even the campus maps are rare.

title: Free, cool shade and comfy chairs
text:
This was a fun surprise after a day of walking.  The colorful metal chairs come in three types, so, seek out the slant back lounger model--the other varieties are straight back no arms, and then there straight back with arms. 

 Match up with the footstools, and you are set for a Cambridge attraction.  There are no tickets, no lines, no rental fees.  Find your favorite expanse of shade, and view the world from this centuries seasoned perch.

title: Elegant, Scenic and Classic
text: For some reason, Harvard University reminds me of University of Dhaka (mostly 60s & 70s). Maybe because of the fact that it has been the center of admiration for such a long time. I found Harvard more welcoming than expected (in terms of visiting the campus). You can roam around the campus as long as you want. The only problem: most of the buildings didn't have names/tags. For first time visitors, it's little difficult to figure out.

title: IS SIMILAR TO OTHER UNIVERSITIES
text: We visited Harvard University during our trip to Boston with group. I liked the campus and the English style buildings of this University, especially the bibliotheq with the Greek architecture like Parthenon. The point visiting a university is not to know it's history, as is easy to get it in internet, but to see all the atmosphere of the whole place. Really Norfolk University at Virginia, where my children are graduated, has nothing less than Harvard, either buildings, gardens, very big bibliotheq and even a school for the kids of students that have no where to leave them during studing at University. I believe that Harvard University is like an attraction at Cambridge after  people that were graduated, became famous.

title: Just for the name! - Nothing else is special
text:
I visited this place only for the reputation it had. As a tourist, it was nothing so great. Didn't get into the museum though. Unless, getting here gives you some inspiration or a satisfaction, I wouldn't recommend this place. 

It is just another university campus - except for the great Harvard brand.. So if you have better things to do, please go ahead.. I wouldn't go again if I get a chance to..

There are some harvard tours too. I don't think it is worth spending on them, unless you badly want to see it..

title: Student Walking Tour of Harvard University 5/6/2013- A great half day activity.
text:
Student Walking Tour of Harvard University 5/6/2013

A great half day activity that doesn't break the bank. Take the 15-20 minute subway trip out to Cambridge and take the Student lead tour through Harvard University. The cost of the trip is $10.00 and money well spent. The tour company is run by Harvard University students and all the proceeds go back to the students. The tour start is located at the main exit  from Cambridge Subway. You will be meet by a person who will direct you to a small newspaper stand where you pay your money and get your ticket.  You then take your ticket back to the person who then gives you a sticker. It is a little round about but it works.

Our tour guide was a third student who was 5 foot and 1 inch tall named Brett (This is how he introduced himself). He was a pocket rocket, he was very enthusiastic about showing the group around, telling great stories of the going on's of the students, pointing out where famous graduates or 'non graduates' lived and studied and informing the group of the history of America's oldest university. The tour is two hours long and finishes at a park just outside the university walls. There is a great cafe located here for lunch and just around the corner is the subway for the trip back to Boston. My wife and I enjoyed it no end.  We explored the campus further after the tour and their Business College campus were beautiful with well manicured gardens!

title: Student Led Tours
text: There are student led tours for free of the campus. It gives you background that walking around the campus would not give you. Stories about how freshman are picked for their upperclassmen house and what happened the morning after the library burned down. When you get off the subway there is an information booth that will point you to where the free tours are. They also sell a great map for 25 cents. The bookstore The Coop is a good place to buy a souvenir. L. A. Burdick is a chocolate shop right by Harvard. Expensive but nice. Your can walk to Brattle Street nearby and take a tour of Longfellow's house. It is an amazing tour and worth the 15 minute walk from the campus.

title: The cradle of American Liberal Arts Education!
text: England has Oxbridge, the US  has Harvard! Lovely setting in the very middle of Cambridge. title: A bit of history - definitely go into the church
text: If you're a tourist in Boston, Harvard University is definitely worth a visit even if it's just to walk around the square to take the history in. It's a good way from the centre of Boston but easily accessible by T line or bus.  We were there when it was pouring with rain so ran for shelter into the church.  This turned out to be a major result as it was stunning and a real example of Boston's historical past. We were doubly lucky in that we had it all to ourselves and then a gentleman started to play the wonderful organ.  It was like a wonderful oasis from the weather and the traffic.

title: Been there got the tee-shirt!
text: It is worth a visit primarily because it is so famous throughout the world. It is good to see what it is all about and has some pretty (if slightly plain) buildings. It certainly is no where near as pretty as the likes of Cambridge and Oxford in the UK. We visited the Natural History Museum which was quite good and you get access to the Peabody museum included. Didn't seem too many (food & drinks) facilties for non students but it was nice to meander around and observe. We enjoyed the John Harvard Statue where local legend has it if you touch his left foot then your IQ will increase; there may be something in this as my wife did and over the next couple of days she did have a couple of very insightful moments!!

title: You should visit when students are not on a break
text: Harvard yard is very strange, when students are on a break.  So, try to schedule your visit when the yard is full of students, going to the libraries or running to the next class. Say "hello" to John Harvard, walk the steps of Widener's library. You can visit it too!  Walk into the Emerson hall, which houses the Philosophy department. Walk out of the yard, and visit the Art museum (from Harvard Square entrance, across the yard)  If you have a full day, see if there is an interesting film at Harvard Film Archives (Carpetner Center, practically next to the Art Museum). If you have more than 1 day for a visit, check out Science center, just across the Harvard Yard and many Harvard Museums.

title: READ BEFORE YOU GO :)
text: I am amazed to see some of the reviews. I do not know what people might expect from a university, particularly such a big one, not to mention the oldest :)  Walk the Harvard yard, go to the museum of your interest - Harvard has many.  Visit the Business School area, to feel the difference :) Attend one of the concerts or a theater performance. Take a walk along Charles, and see the Harvard residential housing.  Before you go, visit the Harvard information web site, or the Information Center in Cambridge

title: Not only historical and beautiful, but a real crossroads.
text: The storied halls of Harvard attract not only students and prospective students, but also tourists from all over the world. They, and the world-class scholars, speakers, and other celebrities constantly passing through, give this stately old quadrangle the excited feel of an axis mundi. You are at the center of the academic world here, and you can feel it in the air. What's more, the Yard is completely open and simple to access ‚Äî just walk in. Unlike the colleges at Yale or Oxford, you are welcome to stroll through and soak in the heady atmosphere. Don't forget to rub John Harvard's left foot for good luck, peek into Memorial Church, and gaze at the massive fa√ßade of Widener Library in the New Yard!

title: Great tour of Harvard Univ from Harvard SQ
text: I was in Boston last week end and saw the volunteers from the Student organization talking about the tour. I love old architecture so I signed up for it. It was fun, funny, well researched and it was special since the students are your guide. You get the insiders view. The tour takes you to the famous yard, walks around the yard and brings you near the book store where you can get souvenir or pay the fees of ten dollars. Its pretty good for the price. Your guide will tell you all the history and fun facts about the campus. Its for an hour and I would recommend it for wanna be Bostonians or Harvardians!

text:

A definite must do for any visitor and well done Alexis!!

title: Feeling history
text: I recently moved back to the Boston area and this time on the far banks of the Charles in Cambridge in Huron Village and walking around my new neighborhood took me to Harvard Yard. The Yard has that mystic and sense of privilege few Americas will ever partake. Especially in this time of shifting morality and values, walking through Harvard embudes one with an understanding of the virtues of intellectual endeavor.

title: Great campus tour; fab staff!!
text: Here on a college visit with my daughter.  It's #1 on her list.  Great tour, very informative & super staff!  Thanks for an awesome visit.  Keeping fingers crossed at application time!  ;). Park in a public lot or watch street signs very closely!  We were warned, but others were not so lucky.  A 10 car length stretch of road could have 3 different parking restriction signs....read the signs carefully!!  We had a nice lunch at Panera across the street & met students (all wonderful) which added to some of our tour questions & hearing things first hand.  A classic & classy college!

title: A pleasant wander on a sunny day
text: I have visited Harvard University on several occasions, the first time because  it was the setting for a novel I enjoyed. Since then it has become a semi-regular haunt, and I have visited several of the buildings as well as wandering the campus. Buildings are widely located so a rainy day is not conducive to a pleasant visit. However, if in Cambridge, it is a must.

title: Beautiful old campus!
text: I enjoyed the self-guided walking tour (pick up a brochure in a nearby info center).  I also enjoyed going into the Houghton Library with rare books and manuscripts. title: Pretty amazing.
text: Don't miss the Sackler Museum. It's small, but it's got an excellent collection, and shouldn't be overlooked if you're in Cambridge. There are tours, both official and unofficial, of Harvard. And restaurants abound. To walk through The Yard is a treat on a Sunday morning, especially since the students are all still asleep in their dorms!

title: Awesome experience, but I  wish I could enter more buildings
text: I have to admit the aura the surrounds Harvard lives up to it's reputation. It's easy to get  via the T, just jump on the outbound Red line.  We went a bit too late to get a tour so we walked round the Campus.We started off at the Harvard Business school which is on the Other side of the Charles River (approx 5min from the main campus) and then walked to the Main Campus. For the most part the buildings are of old architecture and definitely give that prestigious vibe. There is a photo opportunity around each corner. I'd say the one downside is you are not able to enter most buildings. We did enter the Law library after asking and I have to say it was breathtaking. I would definitely recommend trying to get into one of the libraries its totally worth it. Overall Harvard is an amazing place. You can make an afternoon of it by grabbing food at Harvard Square.

title: Nice Place to Walk Around
text: If you are in the area, and you are bored, definitely take some time out of your day to check this out. Harvard University is known world-wide and getting to say that you stepped on some of their land is pretty special if you are visiting internationally. The actual area is quite large, but there is plenty of information available to help you get your way around easily. Lots of history is in the area and there are some pretty awesome spots to get some pictures. Another great thing is that it's right beside MIT, so you can visit both in one day. Visit if you have time!

title: visit the real Harvard --free official tour
text: For an authentic, free tour lead by current Harvard student ambassadors, go to the info center located in the Holoyoke Arcade on Mass Ave. near Harvard Square. title: Bottom line
text: Getting into Harvard is overrated.  The rigor of a Harvard education is also overrated, especially now that we know that cheating is a big problem.  The endowment is the biggest in the nation, and much of the money is being used to encroach upon a lower middle class Boston area known as Alston.  Many graduates become wealthy lawyers, doctors, and investment bankers.  No doubt Harvard students and professors have contributed much to this great country and the university is the elite of the elite.  Just ask anybody there.

title: Must See!
text: Visiting Harvard was like finally "at Harvard". Ivy League and all the hype, it was good to finally see the school that produces some of the world's finest minds. title: Harvard University
text: I remember the Harvard of  1981 when I first came to the area and all of the things that were done differently than are done today.  The Business school and Harvard Real Estate have essentially driven the interesting stores, bars, restaurants, night clubs and booksellers out of the area and replaced them with banks.   While some of it is left  and it is still interesting it is a shadow of what it was.

title: Hard to beat Harvard
text: I had always wanted to visit Harvard and it lived up to my expectations. We took the number 1 bus from the city which dropped us at the Visitors Centre right across from Harvard Yard. We took a 10am free tour hosted by one of the second year students. The guide had an extensive knowledge of the campus its history and fun facts like where Matt Damon lived when he was a student. The guide succeeded in making us very envious of her being a student. The tour was quite structured and while we did go inside one of the building a downside was the lack of access to most buildings which are for students only. The old buildings are magnificent and there are ample photo opportunites but the best part was the guide herself who was fantastic and answered many questions my wife and I had on education in the USA and how it differs from our educational experiences in Australia. Highly recommended.

title: Nice campus
text: This was my first glimpse at an American Ivy League about 10 years ago.  It's a pretty campus, and certainly has an air of prestige, but I'm not sure if it's all cracked up to what people say it is.  I have since visited other non-Ivy league schools such as Stanford and I much prefer the laid back country club style atmosphere I experienced there.  Less snobbery and more relaxed!

title: Absolutely beautiful!
text: One of the highlights of our recent trip to Boston was our visit to Harvard University.  It was so beautiful!  We decided to take a last minute tour with one of the costumed guides standing in the Square. It cost $12 each. title: Nice peaceful setting that makes you feel smarter just being there.
text: On our visit to Cambridge we came upon Harvard Yard. I must have heard of it before,as the name resonates with me. A large green courtyard with might maple trees surrounded by halls of knowledge. There the statue of John Harvard watches in repose as small flocks gather to reflect...Or eat lunch,nap or consult there personal electronic devices. Here on the green are arranged some simple chairs that are quite comfortable to sit in and observe from. Somehow I felt like a scholar as I sat and took it all in. Sun streamed through the trees dressed in there full autumn flame and warmed the hearts of all who took pause...there upon the yard.

title: Nice historic campus
text: As a visitor to Boston/Cambridge it is worthwhile to take one of the walking tours of Harvard University. We took an unofficial tour that was run by a group of Harvard students (its free, but tips are suggested). The students gave us a very interesting overview of the campus and the history of the university buildings as well as several funny incidents along the way. If you cannot take the tour, a simple walk through the campus is nice to get a feel of the institution. Afterwards a walk through Harvard Square, and a visit to the Harvard Coop is a must.

title: A few things to do here
text: Some people may want to see Harvard just to get an idea of what a great university looks like, but there really isn't much to do in Harvard itself.  There are a few museums operated by the university (reviewed separately), but visitors mostly just walk through the courtyards. title: Great tour by Harvard Students
text: This hour long tour is guided by Harvard University students, at a small suggested cost of $10 per person.  The student lead us around a large section of the University highlighting important, well known buildings and structures, giving us great inside information at the same time.  Who knew that Al Gore & Tommy Lee Jones shared a room in their freshmen year, & are still great friends today? We thoroughly enjoyed the tour & were left hungry for more information.  Just go to the information booth in Harvard Square & spend a wonderful hour in an iconic institution.

title: 376 Years Old University
text:
My first visit to Harvard University was over 20 years ago. My first impression was that the campus had some very old buildings, and some of them were closed due to lack of maintenance. It might be there was not enough funding at the time. Recently, I revisited Harvard University, and it completely changed my opinion. I am glad that we made the right decision to learn more about this renowned and historical school. We took the subway to Harvard Square Station and walked to Harvard Information Center in the Holyoke Center Arcade. This was a good start because they offer a free tour of the Harvard Yard, which is led by a senior student. Normally, it has 3 scheduled guided tours (10 am, 12 pm and 2 pm) everyday. It is suggested to check the schedule before you go because it might not have the tours due to various reasons. It is a one-hour walking tour, and it covers most of the campus and its history. You do not need to make a reservation, but sometimes you might need to wait for the next available tour. If you prefer self-guided walking tour, you can visit their mobile tour website.

Harvard University is an American private Ivy League research university which celebrated its 376th anniversary in 2012. It is the oldest institution of higher education in the United States. There are many historic buildings in Harvard Yard. The high Victorian Gothic style Memorial Hall is one of the iconic buildings on the campus. It was built in 1870s to honor the Harvard graduates who fought for the Union in the American Civil War. Today, the Sanders Theatre is a lecture and concert hall, and the Annenberg Hall is used as the dining hall for the freshmen. The interior of Memorial Hall is a must see, and you might need to wait in line because it is the most impressive place on the campus. Another interesting location you can‚Äôt miss is the John Harvard statue and its ‚ÄúStatue of the Three Lies‚Äù. You can easily see his shining shoe because Harvard students and tourists believe rubbing the shoe will bring you luck.

I thought there must have been many directors who use the Harvard campus in their movies. However, I was wrong. Because the movie staff of The Love Story (1970) caused damage to the Harvard campus, the university administration refused most subsequent requests for filming on Harvard.

title: I live near here and really love it
text: There is always something to see in the Yard, even if it is just the buildings, the configuration and the trees.  However, the visitors are great to see, the tours are fun to hear and the mix of faculty, students, visitors, parents and locals is great fun.  Drew Faust had lovely colored chairs put on the lawn of the yard, so people just come and read or eat or talk in the yard.  The Memorial Church and Widener Library face each other and are really impressive; go during graduation and see the magic of the individuals who have worked so hard and their parents.

title: Student Led Tour at Harvard
text: We opted for the 'free', student led tour of Harvard - if you don't enjoy it, you don't pay; if you do, the recommended gratuity is $10.  Our tour was well worth the money. Guide 'Jess Lucy' poked fun at the 'Hahvahd' accent, and shared lots of 'inside' stories from the uni. She pointed out where all the famous graduates were housed, and told short, historical anecdotes at every turn.  Our group was around 20 people from all over the world. The full tour takes an hour and you walk 1.5 miles - at a very leisurely pace, with lots of stops.  A good way to see the campus.

title: Not Worth It
text: If you are going for the architecture then skip it.  Unlike many historical universities around the world Harvard is very bland and boring in both an architectural and interest sense.  Sadly when we went we did not get to take in a tour (they start in mid Sept) which would have provided us with some history but as far as walking around the campus and checking out the architecture it was a total dud.

title: Harvard Univ tour by students
text: This tour is led by students - ours was extremely knowledgeable, with a great personality and delivery style.  We walked through the yard, and onto the extended campus.  Our guide was able to answer our questions and provide us with entertaining history and tid-bits.  The published cost is "free" but with a suggested tip of $10/pp or $20/per family - well worth it!  The tour is offered 7 days/wk Mar - Dec.

title: Interesting walk
text:
We went last weekend, which means moving in weekend for all the new and returning students. It was a lot of fun and very interesting to wander on the campus. Very nice students helped us find the Le Corbusier building, but we all had trouble finding the Gropius Building - unfortunately.
They offer free tours of the campus, run by student volunteers - the one we saw, was so passionate about sharing her stories of Harvard - she was great!

title: Interesting - better with Trip Advisor Guide
text: Walking through Harvard Yard and the entire campus is like strolling through history. If you don't know what you are looking at it could be quite boring. The best option is to download the Boston City Guide available free from Trip Advisor as an application on your smart phone or i-phone. The guide has a Harvard Yard guide that explains each building you are looking at with history and interesting facts. There is also an application called "Every Trail". You can download this too and it has guides as well as GPS driven with live maps. Also FREE and a Trip Advisor company.

title: Enjoyable free history tour
text: I decided to go to visit Harvard after a recommendation from a friend. I'm glad I did as I found it a beautiful, interesting place. I went early and managed to get on a tour with a current student. I would definitely recommend this, as I think without it you would not appreciate the history of the site, or its relevance to the current students. It was also great to see some students moving in, and reminded you that this is still a working university, as well as a place steeped in history.

We took a self-guided tour of Harvard using the free Harvard Yard Tour app, which provides a map plus helpful information on buildings of interest. The place is really worth a visit and easy to tour even without a map.

There were loads of tourists when we were there but that's probably because it was summer.

title: Beautiful campus and great energy
text:
We really enjoyed our visit to Harvard.   The tour we took was helpful, fun & informative, and we got to experience the great energy of the students.  

I can't imagine what it must be like to be a student at this beautiful school, but I think there must be an annoying piece to have to dodge tourists while heading to class.  That being said, everyone we talked to was generous, kind, outgoing and warm.

It was a delightful visit and we recommend it.

title: A Taste of Harvard's Past and Present
text: Walking through Harvard Yard surrounded by the historic buildings, libraries, dorms, and greenery there is a magical feeling in the air. There is definitely a strong feeling of people and events from the past as you stroll about, however, watching the current students studying, chatting, and walking about going to classes or their activities is inspiring and exciting. The Harvard tours are very informative and the students leading the groups are very dedicated and will give you a good history lesson of the sites in the yard.

title: Some history
text:
I got to Harvard with the T, it stops right under Harvard square. So if you want to make it easy for yourself, no traffic, take the T.
As soon as you arrive on the square, you feel a nice, vibrant atmosphere. Immediately you will see the students who will guide you around on Harvard. The difference between old and new on and off the university is worth to see. The old buildings (for the US) are beautiful with attached history.
If you love history, then this is a must do activity!

title: Harvard University
text: Our class of 21 enjoyed our time touring Harvard University. We got to see all of the iconic places in Harvard. We saw the Harvard yard and during our trip, learned many interesting facts about this Ivy League school. After visiting the yard, we went to the library, all of the freshman dorm buildings, the freshman lunch area, the presidents office, the science building, a building with the names of all of the civil war Harvard students, and finally, we stopped at the Natural History Museum in the city of Cambridge. The also has many other shops you can stop at after visiting Harvard. Enjoy your time!

title: Lovely for an afternoon walk
text: Join a free tour at Harvard Square T run by college freshment (who work for tips) and get an interesting insight into this amazing university.  Or take an afternoon stroll with a LIzzy's homemade icream in hand. Make sure you wander through some of the off-campus buildings, such as Harvard Business School or the under-grad dorms near cnr JFK and Elliot Street.

title: amazing history
text: Being the oldest university in the new world, it has a ton of history.  We went on the student tour and found out a lot of amazing facts.  We didn't have time to fully explore the campus and know we missed some of the best parts like the arboretum,  Too bad they only allow Freshman into the elaborate dinning hall or library, but understandably as it is so popular.  The Peabody Museum is worth the admission fee.

title: Must visit
text:
Spend at least half hour or few hours.  If you only have half hour, go to see the statue of John Harvard and touch his left shoe!
Walk few minutes around the 6-7 Harvard buildings and get a great feel.  

For anyone having more time and/or wishing to know more about a history you can take a tour or just attach yourself to any walking tour passing by.  In summer time/weekend there are lots of them happening.

text: Founded in 1636, Harvard is the oldest university in America.  Take the time to stroll around the old Yard, walk up the steps of Weidner library and reflect on all the great minds and famous people who attended this great institution.

title: Visiting the University's historic nucleus.
text:
Located roughly in the center of campus, Harvard Yard is the oldest and arguably most celebrated portion of the campus.  It is roughly divided into two portions: The Old Yard (western third) and everything else, the latter including the Widener Library and Tercentenary Theater.  I toured here first as part of a group (Hahvahd tours ‚Äì see separate review) and then the next day on my own with a tour book.  While at first this may look like a ‚Äúgroup of old buildings with a statue in the middle‚Äù I‚Äôm happy to report that looks in this case are quite deceptive.  Many of these buildings are Centuries old and have history dating to the pre-Revolutionary War period;  Massachusetts Hall at different times housed John Adams, John Hancock, Sam Adams, and a contingent of the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War.  It seemed at every corner I ran into something historically significant (JFK‚Äôs dorm), artistically intriguing (John Harvard‚Äôs statue) or both (Holden Chapel).

You won‚Äôt be spoon fed information while walking around here (sorry, no fancy descriptive plaques or audio guide) but Harvard Yard is as much an integral part of American history as anything else in New England.  Highly recommended.

title: If you've been to Cambridge UK, this is dull.
text:
Americans are very proud of Harvard University. They have buildings dating from the 1800s and lots of advances and studies have been made there. Harvard is unusual in the US, as I understand - redbrick buildings laid out in courts and quads and serious people wandering around thinking serious things. 
Unfortunately, I come from the UK, which has both Cambridge and Oxford universities with buildings dating back to the 1400s and older and the whole place just reeks of history, if that's what you're looking for. 
I understand I could have taken a tour, but the tour that was pushed quite heavily around Harvard was (unsurprisingly) the "alternative and unofficial" student tour, where you pay a student to tell you about their wacky student lifestyle. I didn't fancy that much either. 

I really can't think of much to recommend about Harvard University. As the title says, if you come from the UK and have been or lived in Cambridge or Oxford, or have visited them, Harvard feels very much like a poor relation. But if you've never been to either, you might find it a bit more interesting.

title: You can miss it if you are in Boston
text: I learnt through internet that there were free visits organised by the same university so we went. We showed up at the departure point a couple of minutes earlier. In our group were about 40 people and our guide was a freshman student from New Zealand. He took us around the square and showed us the most important buildings as long as he told us about history, studies and everyday living in the campus. It took about an hour and was very interesting. I strongly recommend it!

title: Campus is nothing special
text: We all agree Harvard University is an excellent university providing outstanding education, but the campus is nothing special. Apart from the name and the ability to say "I was at Harvard" there is not much to see at this venerable institution. Walking around MIT is far more interesting due to the presence of architecturally interesting buildings.

title: At one time George Washington slept here !!
text:
General Washington borrowed Harvard Yard in July ,1775,to use as Americas first Army base during the 11 month long Siege of British occupied Boston. Washington filled the dorms and classrooms with his new US Army, and Martha came to live with the General. 
  Harvard U. was already 139 years old when the American Revolution began. 8 US Presidents have Harvard degrees.

title: SUCKS........so badly...it's not funny
text:
Who the hell was the architect of Harvard??? It sucks! Ugly buildings, red-bricked walls everywhere....it feels like I'm in an abandoned factory in Europe where the windows are cracked (not in Harvard) and the buildings look soo old and unattended....

The only nice places are the Yard, the Dining hall (the one that looks like a Romanic church....yeah....are we in harry potter...?) and the Biology Building, which is my favortie, it has a beach volleyball court in the middle, and animals bas-relieves all over their walls representing different animals in Latin; and then two copper rhinos guarding the entrance and the doors are also sculpted with golden insects and such.

title: As of Dec 2011 - closed to public
text: Just want to let potential visitors that as of Nov or Dec 2011, Harvard Yard is mostly closed to the casual public.  Only Harvard University members (students, faculty, staff, etc.) are permitted to walk within the gates with photo ID.  I imagine if you're on a sanctioned campus tour, it's fine - but if you're just in the area and want to walk around for a few minutes, unfortunately it isn't permitted.

title: Great visit to a historical institution
text: We spent an afternoon in Harvard Square and a couple of hours in Harvard University. Visit the Student Services office located across the street from Harvard and sign up for a free student-led guided tour of the University campus.  Our tour guide was very upbeat and told a few stories of the Universtiy's buildings, traditions, and great stories of the school.  The tour lasts about an hour, but it's a great way to learn a great deal about the school and history.

title: A great day out with T.S.Elliot's room mate!
text: Our Freshman guide, Lenzo, really was terrific. We were the only people on his tour that day (which was free but voluntary donation is welcomed)but he showed no sign of disappointment at having to spend a couple of hours in the company of a pair of pensioners! Indeed he went out of his way to instill his enthusiasm for his university into us. He did the whole tour walking backwards while talking to us about the buildings we were looking at. He had many anecdotes to share which made the tour interesting and fun, including the fact that he was living in T.S. Elliot's old dorm - how cool is that!

title: Pretty spot - interesting history
text: We took a bus from Boston to Cambridge and stopped right outside the Harvard University Information Centre on Mass. Ave. A tour of Harvard Yard was just about to start so we joined on. The tour is free, but a donation is requested. The tour lasted for over an hour and was conducted by one of the students, Emily. She was a very good presenter and told us lots of interesting facts and stories about the history of the university and its buildings, as well as her experiences as a student there. Her enthusiasm for the university was infectious. Harvard Yard itself is a beautiful spot, but the tour brought it all to life, with explanations of what happens where, and who does what. We weren't really expecting to do the tour, but we were so glad we did. If you are visiting Harvard, try to get on a tour - it's much more informative and entertaining than the self-guided brochure.

title: A famous University to visit
text:
This is a university campus you must visit because of all the prestigious that Harvard has. You will see the statues and historic buildings that made it famous.

You can easily take the subway from Boston to Cambridge, there is an specific stop at Harvard University. There are many gift stores and restaurants in the area to enjoy as well. You can also tour the areas around the campus which are easily accessible by walking.

title: Great Afternoon lounging and enjoying Harvard Square
text: With an afternoon to spare I decided to bring the family to Harvard. I figured with 12 year old twins they may be inspired to work harder at school when we got home. Harvard square is a great little trendy area to enjoy a Java and kick back. We sat in a park and just people watched. If Harvard is stressful you sure couldn't tell by hanging out. Spent 3 hours just roaming around campus and I'd recommend for anyone looking for a relaxing afternoon in Boston. Kids enjoyed many of the shops and appreciated the institution.

title: The "free" tour was good, it just wasn't free
text:
A good day trip from Boston on the subway, especially if you have an interest in higher education. The museum of natural history had some pretty good exhibits on glass flowers, minerals, evolution and such things. Art museum was ok.

The "free tour" advertised and run by Harvard undergraduate students was quite good, however it should more accurately be described as a "tip-only" tour. Everyone was expected to tip $10 each (or $20 for family) - this sounds like a scam, but give the tipping culture, is actually not that out of place in USA.

Our guide regaled us with interesting facts and history about the university, the town, and of course the famous students that studied at harvard over the years.

title: Very impressive!
text:
We took the guided tour offered, given by students of the university.  There was about 50 people in our group, but since the tour is mostly outside, it didn't feel crowded.  From what I understand the group was large compared to what they usually get, it was the high season.  The student spoke loudly and clearly, and was quite amusing.  It was very interesting to hear about each of the building - the tour wasn't as much about the history of Harvard as what happens in each building today, and how life is on campus.  The guide was quite candid in answering questions about why he thinks he got in, how much it cost each year, etc., but would preface every answer by making it clear that it was his own experience.

The tour lasted about an hour and it was interesting throughout.  It is free, but the students are not paid, so the only money they make is from the tips that they get.  We gave our tour guide $10.

title: Iconic Institution-a Classic!!
text: While in Boston I stopped in Cambridge to visit Harvard. Wow!! I have been to other Ivy League schools, and this was the most impressive. The old Buildings of red brick just scream history as you look at them. It's a very calm campus. It was fun to walk and see where great historic people and events took place. Spent a couple of hours and enjoyed it. Great place for pics. When in Boston-go check out Harvard. It's a great experience.

title: Very historic... a lovely campus
text:
During vacation times, campus tours are offered to visitors. ¬†Times and information are easy to find on Harvard's website ¬†Unfortunately we arrived a week after these finished for the summer and therefore had to make our own way around. ¬†There is however a very good self guided audio tour and map to download from the Harvard website and I would highly recommend doing this before your visit as you will get so much more out of it. ¬†The best tube to get to is Harvard on the red line and the university is just across the road.
Once in the campus, to be honest there is virtually nothing you can go inside of, the university only allows you to walk around outside. ¬†As long as you keep this in mind and appreciate the exterior of the buildings and the squares you will enjoy your visit.
Some buildings not to be missed are the Memorial Hall, the Henry Widener library, the church opposite the library and the John Harvard statue. It's certainly an area to spend some time in, as the buildings are beautiful and very historic. It's a very calm atmosphere to walk around and you could easily spend an hour or 2 appreciating the history.

title: OK, but not great
text: Took the guided tour of Harvard this morning and the guided tour of MIT this afternoon.  The Harvard tour was OK but all we really saw were the dormitory buildings in Harvard Square.  These were the original classrooms back in the day.  The tour was good if you're interested in the history of Harvard, not so good if you want to know about the school today.  The MIT tour on the other hand was excellent.  They went into both the history of the school as well as the current curriculum.  Both schools are in Cambridge, two stops away from each other on the subway.  Both schools have plentry of places to eat lunch and both sell cool stuff in their book store.

title: Great tour of Harvard University
text:
We took a 10:30 tour of Harvard university led by a Harvard student Eddy. Wow! It was great! Eddy was fun and interesting to listen to. He provided the group with interesting historical facts as well as some funny stories. The tour lasted 90 min and covered a lot of the campus. Unfortunately we didn't go inside any of the halls. But we thoroughly enjoyed the tour.
The tour is free of charge (surprise!) but tips are greatly encouraged. In fact, after such a wonderful tour we wanted to show our appreciation anyway.

title: Magnificent
text:
Was staying in boston and decided to take a short drive over for a view of the renowned harvard campus.

Many of the buildings/infrastructure had such a history to it as evidenced by the design, carvings, material of the building etc. Being able to take a drive through the campus was also a great experience, especially when harvard is a ground for many of the brilliant minds of this world. 

What struck me most was that Harvard had a kind of a city centre for itself and seems very much like a warm, close knitted community.

A truly remarkable experience and makes me wanna study all over again.

title: Great walking tour by the students
text:
Hi

We were visiting Boston over 5th to 8th July and took the metro to Harvard Uni thinking we would just have a quick wander around with the aid of our guidebook. As we came out of the station there were some harvard students milling around in their distinctive t shirts. Asked if we would like to join the tips only walking tour we decided to do just that. Best idea of the day! Our guide was a third year government law student who was full of enthusiasum, anecdotes, history and a blast to be with. The tour last about 1 1/2 hours and was pretty hard-paced, but you saw such a lot and learnt far more than you would from the guidebooks. Highly recommended. They suggest $10 per person and we were more than happy to hand over our $20 dollars at the end. The tour ends at the student gift shop which is run by the students and all profits are ploughed back into helping students. Prices were very reasonable - much cheaper than in Boston and I managed to get a uni hoodie for my daughter (who is off to uni in the UK soon) for about $15 dollars cheaper than I had saw in Boston. Around the gift shop there are plenty of places to eat and we had a late lunch at a great student pub, again very reasonable.

If you only have a short time to see Harvard I would definitely recommend this walking tour.

title: Harvard U-must see!
text: We toured Harvard University in Cambridge with a university student for FREE! The tour lasts about an hour and gives you great insight into Harvard's long storied past. Just sign up at the student center. Tours run throughout the day.The university is a short subway ride from downtown Boston. You can then have a bite to eat anywhere in the area-lots to chose from. It's a must see attraction.

title: Beautiful school with lots of history
text:
We took a tour led by students working for a Harvard store. They were easy to spot with their "Hahvahd" shirts and energy. They took us on a quick, lively tour of the school. We enjoyed the humor and energy of the students. 

Please note that this is not a "free" tour, but runs on tips and is basically a sales pitch for the store, which is where the tour ends; however if you just want a quick tour, this is the one to go on.

title: Be sure to visit not only the old-yard! Several other places of H great too.
text: Most tourists visit only the Harvard old-yard (around Harvard Hall and the freshman housing), either via the Hahvahd/Harvard tour or by themselves. Make sure you visit also the Memorial Hall (dining hall Freshman) at the rear entrance (front entrance only for H-students), the Harvard Museum of Natural History and one of the Harvard Art Museums. If you have time left, stroll via Adam's House / Quincy house towards the Charles River and bring a visit to the Harvard Business School campus. You are able to enter most of the buildings, for instance the Bloomberg Library with a small exhibition. Just orientate more instead of only the old-year with the squirrels.

title: High energy tour...great for tweens and teens!
text: We highly recommend the "Hahvahd" Tour guided by Harvard students. ¬†Our girls, especially, appreciated the humor and interesting tidbits from these very enthusiastic tour guides! It's fast paced...and, at least on our tour, we didn't enter any buildings which was a disappointment for me...but just fine with my tweenage kids.  Fun trivia and some history without spending an entire day (which I would have loved as well!)

title: Tour of Harvard University - A must!
text: On our recent vacation to Boston, we wanted to have our high school aged daughter take a look at Harvard's campus. We took the subway to Harvard and fully intended to merely walk around the campus on our own. As soon as we exited the subway station we were greeted by three delightful Harvard students advertising their "Hahvahd tour". They were so humourous that we decided to go along with it. Fee is by donation only and lasts approximately 1 1/2 hours. We had a blast! I am SOOOO glad that we went on this tour. Gabrielle was our guide and she was wonderful! My father graduated from Harvard many moons ago and I thought I knew many stories. Gabrielle gave us so much of harvard's history that the general public just does not know. She presented the entire tour as a 'story teller' and really made it all come to life. (I know she said she was an "English concentrator", but she sure has a knack for public speaking!) We came home telling my father stories that not even 'he' did not know! The history behind the library is truly a great one. If you plan on going to Cambridge to see Harvard, excuse me..."Hahvahd",  you MUST take this tour. Cambridge and Harvard are beautiful areas....close to a big city...small town atmosphere....intellectual vibe....benches, parks, birds singing. Nice.

My father graduated from Harvard many moons ago and I thought I knew many stories. Gabrielle gave us so much of harvard's history that the general public just does not know. She presented the entire tour as a 'story teller' and really made it all come to life. (I know she said she was an "English concentrator", but she sure has a knack for public speaking!) We came home telling my father stories that not even 'he' did not know! The history behind the library is truly a great one. If you plan on going to Cambridge to see Harvard, excuse me..."Hahvahd",  you MUST take this tour. Cambridge and Harvard are beautiful areas....close to a big city...small town atmosphere....intellectual vibe....benches, parks, birds singing. Nice.

title: The Most Student Friendly City
text:
A stay in Boston is incomplete without a visit to Harvard University, Freedom Trail, Prudential Towers and the Harvard Museum of Natural History.

My visit to Harvard University turned out to be very different in a decidedly intellectual way. The first stop was the Harvard Business School. To walk in the corridors of the world‚Äôs Best Business School is a totally awe inspiring experience that takes you back in time. 

Within the Harvard campus, I stumbled upon a stone edict dating back to 1636!

Next, I hopped across Charles over the Pedestrian Bridge from HBS into Cambridge which led me to Harvard Square. 

Harvard Square is an ideal weekend getaway for students from both Harvard and MIT. And if you get hungry due to the walk, what could be more irresistible than a hot bowl of soup with rich Indian spices at the Bombay Club that I found cuddled in a corner of JFK Street.

title: Wandering the Unviersity Campus
text: Wandering around the Cambridge campus of Harvard is a pleasant way to get from one end of Cambridge to another.  The architecture is impressive (although now an amalgam of old and new buildings and styles), and on a good day, sitting on the lawn in front of the Widener Library playing with the squirrels is a stress reducing activity.  It's one of the top universities in the world, and does have that traditional 'sandstone' feel about it.  Because it is a university populated by students though, you might also see some odd sights, as we did the day we were there in January. The sun was out, and the sky was blue, and there was a group of three women in bikinis on the lawn.  Mind you, the temperature was about 3 degrees celsius at the time, so I'm not sure if they were on a dare, and I am sure they wouldn't have stayed there for very long!   Because the campus is so spread out, it's probably not a typical 'tourist' destination, but I would recommend wandering through the campus instead of walking around it if you get the chance.

Even if you can't get inside the buildings, a stroll through Harvard Yard gives you an idea of the power and influence of this university. The oldest buildings are 300 years old and once housed George Washington's troops, but you can also admire Le Corbusier's only work of art in North America (the Carpenter Center for Visual Arts) or Renzo Piano's beautiful extension to the Harvard Museum of Arts.
More than 100 nationalities are represented on the campus, which has been home to more than 60 Nobel Prize winners.
The quality of the facilities, the richness of the heritage, the diversity of the disciplines taught and the laboratories demonstrate the superiority of the American system of research and higher education.

The library is a beautiful newer building in my opinion. It contains over 15 million books. This makes Harvard the largest university library in the world.

Just in front, you can see people having their photo taken in front of the statue of John Harvard. His bronze foot is gleaming from friction.

We wandered around the campus, as no indoor visits are allowed.

Several U.S. presidents and Nobel Prize winners have visited here.

We really enjoyed this visit, this moment of relaxation, calm and nature.

translated_text: Harvard's main campus is huge. Many people think that Harvard is only made up of the buildings around the statue of John Harvard, but it's much bigger, it's practically a mini city. The curious thing is that the course buildings and dormitories are mixed in with other establishments such as supermarkets and restaurants, so that it is difficult to demarcate the campus. Of course, the main campus is the statue. Visitors can move around freely, but are not allowed to enter the facilities. I recommend taking the student-guided tour (it costs 12 U$ per person and lasts about 2 hours) and/or downloading the Harvard Yard Tour app to hear about each of the buildings. If you're into running, it's also worth taking a run around the campus on the other side of the river, near the stadium. I did this because I wanted to see the university's business and management facilities. Anyway, if you're an academic or just an admirer of one of the richest, oldest and most influential universities in the world, it's worth setting aside a morning or afternoon just to see it.

Of course there are students, but there are also many tourists. There is a line to touch the statue's feet, and the goods store (co-op) seems to be thriving.

Even in the campus, the area of the law school where "Cutie Blonde" was set was deserted, and there were only a few real students (or people who looked like students).

When I went to the Co-op, I bought a binder with the Harvard crest on it and a ring notebook to set it in. It is well made, and I have one that I bought many years ago with no wear on the corners. It's heavy, but that's just as cool.
I also bought a fancy pink tote bag. The stitching on this one is a little loose, but it works well.
It is different from common goods that break easily ^_^.

title: Eccellente e maestosa!

Un campus da sogno, parchi meravigliosi e ben tenuti, dipartimenti distribuiti in molteplici edifici! Per non parlare poi della biblioteca del Dipartimento di giurisprudenza, dove mi sono trovata a condurre le mie ricerche!! La maestosit√† delle forme architettoniche, i quadri, l'ambiente elegante lasciano senza fiato... e poi si gode del silenzio e della concentrazione necessari!

Thanks to the great opportunity to complete my dissertation in the U.S., I found myself in front of the imposing and enormous structure of Harvard University!
A dream campus, wonderful and well-maintained parks, departments spread across multiple buildings! Not to mention the Law Department library, where I found myself conducting my research!!! title: Imperdible visita estando en Boston
text: Si est√°s en Boston, debes ir de visita al campus de la Universidad de Harvard. Se llega f√°cilmente con la l√≠nea roja del metro, descendiendo en la Harvard Square, justo enfrente de uno de los ingresos al campus, que es totalmente libre. Conviene hacer una visita guiada, previo paso por el centro de visitantes que se halla a 100 metros. Cuando estuvimos nosotros, estas visitas estaban algo restringidas, pero nos proveyeron de un folleto muy did√°ctico para autoguiarse. El campus principal es un lugar arbolado, tranquilo, de f√°cil caminata y que transmite un gran clima de estudio y conocimiento. Hay peque√±os rincones deliciosos con bancos, donde los alumnos leen o conversan. Algunos sitios s√≥lo est√°n reservados para estudiantes y personal, lo cual es l√≥gico para no entorpecer la vida cotidiana. Aconsejo salirse del campus antiguo y visitar la facultad de ciencias, al otro lado de la calle, un edificio moderno, en el que se pueden ver las aulas, de extra√±a simpleza, exenta de suntuosidad, que uno puede esperar encontrar en una de las universidades m√°s caras. En algunas es posible incluso ver la actividad de alumnos y docentes. Tambi√©n hay en el hall central una interesant√≠sima exhibici√≥n de la evoluci√≥n del ordenar, desde su origen hasta nuestros d√≠as. Por √∫ltimo, nos impresion√≥ la majestuosidad de la Memorial Church. Tambi√©n conviene recorrer algunas calles aleda√±as del barrio. Toda la actividad dura unas 3/4 horas.
translated_text: If you are in Boston, you must visit the Harvard University campus. It is easily reached on the red line of the subway, getting off at Harvard Square, right in front of one of the entrances to the campus, which is completely free. It is advisable to take a guided tour, after passing through the visitor center, which is 100 meters away. When we were there, these tours were somewhat restricted, but we were provided with a very didactic brochure for self-guiding. The main campus is wooded, quiet, easy to walk around, and conveys a great atmosphere of study and knowledge. There are delightful little nooks with benches, where students read or chat. Some places are reserved only for students and staff, which is logical so as not to hinder daily life. I recommend leaving the old campus and visiting the faculty of science, across the street, a modern building, where you can see the classrooms, of strange simplicity, devoid of sumptuousness, that one might expect to find in one of the most expensive universities. In some of them it is even possible to see the activity of students and teachers. In the central hall there is also a very interesting exhibition of the evolution of ordering, from its origin to the present day. Finally, we were impressed by the majesty of the Memorial Church. It is also a good idea to walk through some of the surrounding streets of the neighborhood. The whole activity lasts about 3/4 hours.

title: Un paseo recomendable
text:
Una ma√±ana decidimos ir a visitar Harvard University. Quer√≠amos conocer ese famoso campus universitario del que hab√≠amos o√≠do hablar desde siempre. As√≠ que luego de desayunar, una fr√≠a ma√±ana, salimos de nuestro hotel en cambridge y agarramos la calle. Preferimos ir caminando antes que hacerlo por otros medios y no nos arrepentimos. Tomamos la Cambridge St desde estaci√≥n Lechmere y (la verdad vali√≥ la pena) disfrutamos del paisaje urbano muy pintoresco.
El campus es un lugar muy bonito lleno de edificaciones de diverso dise√±o y tama√±o, en medio de grandes √°rboles y con muchos senderos por donde no dejan de pasar estudiantes y profesores. Se siente el ambiente estudiantil y, a la vez, se percibe un aire de tarde de domingo por lo silencioso del lugar. Adem√°s, tengo entendido, hay varios museos (historia natural, arte, etc.) que nosotros no visitamos.
Vale la pena visitar Harvard. Un paseo nada estruendoso, pero interesante por lo que representa, su historia y la belleza del lugar.
translated_text:
One morning we decided to visit Harvard University. We wanted to see this famous university campus that we had heard about forever. So after breakfast, one cold morning, we left our hotel in Cambridge and took the street. We preferred to walk rather than go by other means and we didn't regret it. We took Cambridge St from Lechmere station and (it was well worth it) enjoyed the very picturesque cityscape.
The campus is a very beautiful place full of buildings of different design and size, in the middle of big trees and with many paths where students and professors keep passing by. You can feel the student atmosphere and, at the same time, there is an air of a Sunday afternoon because of the quietness of the place. In addition, I understand there are several museums (natural history, art, etc.) that we did not visit.
Harvard is worth a visit. It is not a loud walk, but interesting for what it represents, its history and the beauty of the place.

title: Harvard Stupenda
text:
E' la prima visita che ho organizzato non appena arrivata a Boston che consiglio vivamente di visitare. Il campus √® bellissimo, pulito, ordinato, pieno di ragazzi e ragazze che corrono a destra e sinistra fra una lezione ed una conferenza. Per me √® stata una bella esperienza da ex universitaria questo √® un piccolo sogno che si avvera, almeno in parte, perch√© non √® possibile visitare l'interno delle aule o della famosissima biblioteca, peccato!
E' molto semplice raggiungere il campus basta prendere la linea rossa da Boston e scendere alla fermata omonima in circa 15 minuti di tragitto, la fermata √® proprio davanti all'entrata principale.
translated_text:
It is the first visit I arranged as soon as I arrived in Boston that I highly recommend visiting. The campus is beautiful, clean, orderly, full of boys and girls running around left and right between classes and lectures. For me it was a great experience as a former college student this is a little dream come true, at least partially, because you cannot visit the inside of the classrooms or the very famous library, too bad!
It is very easy to get to the campus just take the red line from Boston and get off at the stop of the same name in about a 15-minute ride, the stop is right in front of the main entrance.

title: Me gustar√≠a estudiar all√≠...
text: En el 2016 tuve la oportunidad de visitar Boston, particularmente recorrer a pie el campus urbano de la Universidad de Harvard. Me impresion√≥ ver sus edificios hist√≥ricos, los parques interminables y sobre todo sus inmensas bibliotecas. ¬øC√≥mo me gustar√≠a estudiar all√≠? Como era la hora del almuerzo pudimos compartir ese tiempo en el comedor universitario junto a estudiantes de diferentes pa√≠ses. La pasamos muy bien y luego de caminar por los alrededores de Cambridge, seguimos viaje en metro al centro de Boston.
translated_text: In 2016 I had the opportunity to visit Boston, particularly to walk around the urban campus of Harvard University. I was impressed to see its historic buildings, the endless parks and especially its huge libraries. How would I like to study there? As it was lunch time we were able to share that time in the university dining hall with students from different countries. We had a great time and after walking around Cambridge, we took the subway to downtown Boston.

translated_text:
During a short overnight trip to Boston in May 2016, I went to the famous Harvard University on the word of a friend who recommended having lunch at a hamburger store in front of Harvard University and taking a walk around Harvard University.
Boston in May was warm and a little hot, so it was very comfortable and the scenery was so beautiful that I really hated to leave. LOL!
Harvard University was also very impressive with its lush greenery, blue sky, green, and beige school buildings.
The statue of Harvard University is open to the public, and there is a jinx that if you stroke the legs of the statue, you will be admitted to Harvard University. The statue is filled with young people who seem to be Harvard applicants.
However, there were also many Chinese and Korean people behaving in a vulgar and offensive manner.
However, Boston in May is still very beautiful, so why don't you go and touch the legs of the Harvard statue? (^ ^)
By the way, I recommend taking the subway because Boston's subway system is very accessible to major tourist attractions.
It is rather expensive (2.75üí≤ for a single ticket), but it is a good way to get to the main attractions. However, if you purchase a day pass, you can ride as much as you want for about 20üí≤.
The great thing about the Boston subway is that it is not a one-day pass like in Japan (only for the day you buy it), but a true one-day pass that is valid for 24 hours from the time you buy it! LOL!
I highly recommend purchasing a one-day subway ticket for Boston!

translated_text:
I was enchanted by the architectural beauty of the place, beautiful red brick buildings amidst small squares and trees. I could only imagine the pride of studying there. It's a shame we couldn't visit the inside of these buildings (I don't know if this is always the case, but at the time of our visit the students were taking exams and didn't allow us access). Even so, it was very worthwhile, as the place is beautiful, charming and worthy of beautiful photos. For those who want more information, there is a self-guided tour starting from Harvard Square. Around the campus there are many shops selling university souvenirs.
Don't miss it. It's easy to get to from Boston, the red subway line to Alewife, get off at Harvard station and you'll be in Harvard Square. Short and fast transportation. On your way back, take the opportunity to visit MIT, just get off at Kendall/MIT station.

From the outset, in addition to all its prestige, the university stands out for its grandiose red brick structures (which, by the way, are very typical of the entire Massachusetts region), and which are likely to look very familiar to you because they have been the setting for several films such as Indomitable Boy, A Father's Love and the obvious The Social Network, which tells the story of Mark Zuckerberg and the creation of Facebook right there, inside those brick walls!

In addition to Zuckerberg and other great figures from history, other personalities still active today also studied there: Barack Obama, George W. title: Paseo imperdible
text: Es una excelente excursi√≥n. Se llega en subte desde el centro de Boston en aprox 15/20 minutos. Es recomendable hacerlo con un tour, hay variedad, desde tour gratuitos que ofrecen los estudiantes de la universidad hasta "free walking tour". Es una lugar impresionante, con muchisima historia. La ciudad alrededor (Cambridge) es muy pintorezca y hay lindos lugares para comer algo. La universidad en s√≠ es imponente, no se puede entrar a los edificios (salvo uno), pero vale la pena recorrerla y aprender las historias que ofrece.

It is advisable to do it with a tour, there is a variety, from free tours offered by the students of the university to "free walking tour". It is an impressive place, with a lot of history. The surrounding city (Cambridge) is very picturesque and there are nice places to eat something. The university itself is impressive, you can't enter the buildings (except for one), but it's worth touring it and learning the stories it offers.

title: Des musees a visiter
text: Il faut absolument voir le musee des sciences naturelles. Un seul etage donc pas trop long a visiter. Il ne faut pas rater les fleurs en verre vraiment extraordinaire. Jaibcp aime le musee geologique et sur les changements climatiques. Campus tres grands pas tres bien indique mais les gens se font un plaisir fe nous renseigner.

title: Il fascino dell'istituzione
text:
Harvard va visitata in quanto e' il simbolo mondiale degli studi universitari.

Siamo capitati fortunatamente il giorno dell'inserimento delle matricole e quindi ..... una sbirciatina siamo riusciti a darla.

Harvard should be visited as it is the world symbol of university studies.
As with MIT I recommend not wasting time and money on guided tours but enjoying a nice walk through the austere but pleasant environment, also because you cannot enter any of the buildings.
We happened to be there fortunately on freshman induction day, so ..... a peek we were able to take.

translated_text:
Not because it is famous.
I think it is the oldest university in the United States. The campus area is calm.
I know more about the top 100 universities in the U.S. than most counselors, including what kind of students they have, what majors they have, and what their graduation rates are.
I can assure you that Harvard is a great university. I think it is the best in the world.
They have a lot of money for research, and they have the most money in the world, so their tuition is cheap.
Compared to other universities, it is not geeky, not extremely liberal or conservative.
It's not a bunch of spoiled kids screaming like idiots every night, and it's not all studying to death.
It is not mammoth like a state university, although some have pointed out that class sizes are too large and professors don't teach,
The students are all smart, so they don't drop classes.
Even if an assistant teaches, the quality of the assistant is better than a poor professor.
The university is very famous for medicine and law, but it is also strong in Japanese studies.
The writer Haruki Murakami was there for a while.

title: Sono rimasto deluso
text:
Ho partecipato alla visita organizzata per la presentazione dell'Universita' e devo dire che quale che fosse il loro messaggio, 
 non mi e' arrivato. Prima siamo stati in una grande aula insieme ad altre duecento persone ad ascoltare l'introduzione di una funzionaria dell'istituto e due studenti, poi ci hanno portato in visita ai vari edifici che compongono l'ateneo senza pero' entrare mai all'interno......una vera delusione.....se da questa visita fosse dipesa l'iscrizione ed il pagamento della relativa astronomica retta, mi sarei rivolto altrove. Forse si fanno forti del loro nome e sanno che le persone si iscrivono comunque......dovrebbero pero' andare a vedere come si propongono con maggiore profusione di notizie le altre universita' ed adeguarsi.
translated_text:
I attended the visit organized for the University presentation and I must say that whatever their message was,
 it did not get through to me. First we were in a large lecture hall along with two hundred other people listening to an introduction by an institute official and two students, then they took us on a tour of the various buildings that make up the university without ever going inside......a real disappointment.....if enrollment and payment of the related astronomical tuition had depended on this visit, I would have gone elsewhere. Perhaps they stand by their name and know that people will enroll anyway......they should, however, go and see how other universities pitch themselves with greater profusion and adjust.

Ric is a blues guitarplayer. I met him one day on 
The green pastures of the Harvard University.'

translated_text: The drive from New York City takes 5 hours. The city of Cambridge is part of the Boston agglomerate and is located 5 km from its center. It is a must-see. Eight US presidents graduated from Harvard University, 75 Nobel Prize winners were associated with it. Entrance to the university campus is free, you can walk around and plunge into the atmosphere of the oldest university, see the territory, academic buildings and student dormitories. Students conduct an hour-long tour of the campus, tell the history of the university, about the mores and customs of Harvard. Even the time here is its own, "Harvard time" - it is shifted by +7 minutes from the time appointed for the lecture. translated_text:
Speaking of tourist attractions in Boston, I came to Harvard University.
Take the train and get off at Harvard University Station. It took me a while just to look around the goods at the coop near the station. Somehow, they were selling goods of MIT, which is also a rival school.
The campus is huge, and there are some familiar buildings such as the East Asia Institute. There were many Chinese people who seemed to be students, and it was rather rare to see white students. There were even some squirrels on campus, which made for a peaceful time.
The medical campus is also far away from the campus, but I recommend it.
